subsection.heading: 1.1 Focus movement in generative syntax: an overview
subsection.p: This chapter is concerned with the way focus movement has been analyzed in generative syntax. In languages like Hungarian, discourse functions such as topic or focus are associated with a particular syntactic position. In other words, constituents that serve as the focus or topic of the utterance are displaced from their canonical position in the sentence.

All the analyses in the generative syntax literature agree that the displacement of focus in these languages is an instance of movement. The analyses diverge with respect to the nature of the movement and its trigger. There are two major trends in the literature, as it happens, following the historical development of the field, and a third, newly emerging one. Let us take these in turn.

The first group of analyses argued that focus assignment is similar to case assignment as both are assigned under government in S-structure. The earliest analysis of Hungarian focus movement is due to Horvath (1986). She proposed that a constituent has to appear in the governing domain of the verb in order to be focused. This is what triggers focus movement. Since focus assignment is argued to take place under government at S-structure, there is an obvious parallel with case assignment in languages like English. One of the main advantages of this proposal is that it predicts a directionality effect: languages that govern to the left have focus movement targeting a left-adjacent position to the verb, while languages with rightward-oriented government have immediately postverbal focus positions. It turns out that this directionality effect shows up in many languages. What one might call a disadvantage of this theory is that it does not readily provide an explanation of the wide-spread similarities between focus constituents and wh-elements. Focus movement exhibits quantificational properties and several syntactic and semantic properties of operator-variable dependencies, such as weak crossover and parasitic gap licensing.

This brings us to the second group of analyses of focus movement, whose main tenet is that focus movement is like wh-movement. The main advantage of this idea is that it explains both syntactic and semantic considerations that establish a parallel between focus movement and wh-movement. The earliest analysis, due to Brody (1990b) and Rizzi (1996), proposed that focus movement, just like wh-movement, is triggered by the Focus criterion and the Wh-criterion. The focus/wh-element has to appear in a specifier–head relationship with its licensor. As checking theory became full-blown, the new analyses proposed specific functional head positions, such as the Focus head, to provide a licensor for the moved focus (e.g., Brody 1995a; Rizzi 1997). There are several advantages to this group of theories. First, the proposed specifier–head licensing accounts for the often-attested adjacency effects between focus/wh and verb (or Infl). It provides an explanation for the occurrence of pied-piping in focus movement, as pied-piping is a well-known characteristic of wh-movement as well. This is not to say that there are no open questions. In particular, an important issue concerns the status of alleged weak crossover violations involving focus movement. There is an alternative way to account for these data, one that argues that the ungrammaticality of these examples does not stem from a syntactic violation, rather a discourse violation. If so, this undermines the very basis of the analysis of focus movement, in terms of wh-movement, as it removes an important syntactic parallel between focus movement and wh-movement.

A newly emerging set of analyses capitalizes on the well-known but long-neglected generalization that the focus constituent always bears main prosodic prominence (Chomsky 1971). Until very recently, the fact that, at least in languages like English, the focus constituent bears main stress was regarded as irrelevant for the syntax of focus. All the analyses before had regarded focus as the primary property of syntax; prosody was secondary. In other words, in order to ensure that the focal constituent receives main stress, it was assumed that main stress gets assigned to the constituent that was marked focus in syntax. Thus, all these analyses conformed to what Ladd (1996) called the accent-to-focus view. The new set of analyses takes just the opposite perspective. It is not accent that matches focus, but rather focal interpretation is attached to the constituent that bears accent; this is the focus-to-accent view. One of the main advantages of this approach is that it provides a natural account for certain empirical facts; for instance, for the existence of focus projection. Another, more conceptual, advantage is that it provides a way to conform to Chomsky's (1995c) Inclusiveness condition, which all accent-to-focus views violate. The focus-to-accent view faces empirical and conceptual issues of its own. For instance, arguably, it assumes a certain kind of look-ahead property, and is therefore incompatible with the T-model as the architecture of the grammar.

This chapter is organized in the following way. This section provides an introduction. First, some preliminary discussion is put forth (section 1.2). The basic concepts such as focus and focus movement are defined and the scope of the chapter is determined. The notion of focus is examined briefly, from both a discourse-pragmatic and a semantic perspective, and a brief review is provided of positions available in the wider linguistic literature on the grammatical encoding of focus. Then the basic syntactic and semantic characteristics of focus movement are described with the help of Hungarian data (section 1.3). The bulk of the chapter is in sections 2–4. Here, one by one, the major lines of analyses concerning focus movement are reviewed. In particular, section 2 concerns analyses that argue that focus assignment is under government and thus liken focus to case; section 3 describes some analyses that draw a parallel between focus and wh; and section 4 explains the focus-to-accent view. In all of these sections, the last subsection (i.e., sections 2.4, 3.5, and 4.4) contains a discussion of the main advantages and disadvantages of the line of argumentation under consideration. These subsections are inevitably more speculative than the rest of the section, as their aim is to provide an evaluation of the proposals in both empirical and theoretical terms. Section 5 concludes the chapter.

subsection.heading: 1.2 Preliminaries
subsection.p: This introduction has three aims. First, the notions of focus and focus construction are defined in a way that is as theory-neutral as possible but nevertheless restrictive enough to determine the set of phenomena under consideration. This will allow for the conclusion that cleft constructions and constructions like English Heavy NP Shift are outside the scope of this chapter (section 1.2). Second, the basic syntactic and semantic characteristics of focus constructions are exemplified with Hungarian data. Two syntactic characteristics that are crucial for further discussion are identified: (i) focus is immediately adjacent to the verb; (ii) focus and wh-elements are in complementary distribution (section 1.3). Third, Horvath's (1986) arguments in favor of a movement analysis of the Hungarian focus construction are summarized (section 1.3.2).

subsection.heading: 1.2.1 Definition of focus and the wh-test
subsection.p: A well-formed sentence satisfies all the syntactic, semantic, morphological, and phonological principles of the grammar, and the utterance is an expression of the given language. This does not imply, however, that the utterance of such a sentence can be used appropriately in any discourse context. Discourse is organized by information packaging devices, such as topic, focus, etc. If the information structure of a particular expression does not match the information packaging required by the context, the expression is infelicitous in that context, albeit grammatically well-formed. For instance, the utterance in (1b) is not felicitous in the context of (1a), even though it is a well-formed expression of English: 1

(1)
a. What did John eat?
b. #John ate the pizza.

It is a well-known characteristic of wh-questions that they require an answer whose focus is the constituent corresponding to the wh-phrase. In (1b), the focus of the utterance is on the subject, John. In contrast, the wh-question in (1a) requires an answer whose focus is the direct object. As a result of this incompatibility of information structure, (1b) is not appropriate in the context of (1a). The incompatibility of the question–answer pair in (1) indicates that certain aspects of information structure are grammatically encoded: the utterance in (1b) has some grammatical properties that disallow it in the context of the wh-question in (1a), requiring focus on the object.

In this work, focus is taken to be the part of an utterance that is new or asserted. The rest of the utterance is the background (or in some cases the presupposed part). In particular, a diagnostic test to identify the focal part of an utterance is the wh-test. As was mentioned above, the part of the utterance that provides the answer to a wh-question is the focus. So, the focus of the answer in (2) is the DPDO:

(2)
Q: What did John eat?
A: John ate the pizza.

subsection.heading: 1.2.2 Different types of focus: semantic and pragmatic differences
subsection.p: Different types of focus have been identified in the literature. These include semantico-pragmatic distinctions such as contrastive focus (Rochemont 1986) (3a), identificational focus (Kiss 1998) (3b), or new information focus (3c). Also, focus can be wide (or broad), as in (3c), or narrow, as in (3a) (Chomsky 1971). In this work, all these are taken to be part of the (general) notion of focus:

(3)
a. I hate broccoli, not zucchini.
b. A brokkolit utálom. Hungarian
the broccoli-acc hate-I
‘It's broccoli that I hate.’
c. A: Do you have any special requirements for food?
B: I hate broccoli.

subsection.heading: 1.2.3 On the semantics of focus
subsection.p: This is not to say that there are no semantic or pragmatic distinctions between the different types of focus. Szabolcsi (1981b) argued that the preverbal focus position in Hungarian is associated with exhaustive listing in a way that is directly reflected in the truth-conditions of the utterance. Thus a sentence like (4a) means something like (4b):

(4)
a. A tanári
Jánosnakj
adott jelest ti tj.
the teacher John-dat gave A+-acc
‘The teacher gave an A+ to John.’ (Kiss 1994: 27, ex. 55)
b. John is the only person amongst the members of the class (or some other set of people who could have gotten A+) that the teacher gave an A+ to.

In other words, there is a focus operator that checks every member of the contextually given relevant set for the property in question (here the property of receiving A+ from the teacher) and identifies John as the single member of that set of whom the property is true. Similar semantics has been proposed for the English cleft construction and for the focus-sensitive operator only (e.g., Rooth 1992). (See Rooth 1996 for an overview of the semantics of focus.)

As strong support for the semantic nature of focus, Szabolcsi (1981b) demonstrated that focusing has an effect on the truth-conditions of the sentence. For instance, compare (5) and (6). (5b) is a logical consequence of (5a), while this is not true of (6b) and (6a). Consequently, conjoining either (6a) or (6b) with the negation of the other one does not yield a contradiction. This is shown in (7):

(5)
a. Jánosi
magával vitte Marit és Évát ti.
John self-com took Mary-acc and Eva-acc
‘John took Mary and Eva with him.’
b. Jánosi
magával vitte Marit ti.
John self-com took Mary-acc
‘John took Mary with him.’ (Kiss 1994: 28, ex. 59)

(6)
a. Jánosi
[Marit és Évát]j
vitte magával ti tj.
John Mary-acc and Eva-acc took self-com
‘It was Mary and Eva that John took with himself.’
b. Jánosi
Maritj
vitte magával ti tj.
John Mary-acc took self-com
‘It was Mary that John took with him.’ (Kiss 1994: 29, ex. 60)

(7)
Jánosi
nem [Marit és Évát]j vitte magával ti tj. hanem Maritj
vitte magával ti tj.
John not Mary-acc and Eva-acc took self-com but Mary-acc took self-com
‘It was not Mary and Eva but Mary that John took with him.’
(Kiss 1994: 29, ex. 61)
The same is true for sentences involving only and clefts in English:

(8)
a. John invited only Mary and Eve. He didn't invite only Mary.
b. It was Mary and Eve that John invited, not Mary.
c. *John invited Mary and Eve. He didn't invite Mary.

However, there is evidence that exclusion may sometimes be absent from the meaning of preverbal focus in Hungarian (Kiss 1987). In these cases, only identification is present. Indefinites often have this property. So, for instance, (9) does not presuppose the existence of a set of groups of people, identifying the set of actors as the only relevant one for which it is true that they are reading in the garden. It simply identifies the set of people that are reading in the garden as actors:

(9)
A kertbeni
színészekj
olvasnak fel ti tj.
the garden-loc actors read prt
‘In the garden, actors are reading out loud.’
(based on Kiss 1994: 28, ex. 56)

Similarly, numerals also only express identification and not exclusion. Even though (10b) means that it is exactly 30,000 forints that John spends a month, this is not the result of an operation where 30,000 would be identified as the only member of the set of natural numbers such that John spends that many forints in a month. Rather, as (10b) indicates, focusing the numeral has the effect that an ‘exactly’ rather than an ‘at least’ reading is associated with the numeral (Szabolcsi 1981b):

(10)
a. Jánosi
elkölt 30 000 forintot egy hónapban ti tj.
John prt-spends 30,000 forints-acc a month-loc
‘John spends (at least) 30,000 forints a month.’
b. Jánosi
30 000 forintot
költ el egy hónapban ti tj
John 30,000 forints-acc spends prt a month-loc
‘John spends exactly 30,000 forints a month.’ (Kiss 1994: 28, ex. 58)

The fact that exhaustivity disappears in these cases suggests that a sufficiently refined semantic analysis of focus is required to be capable of taking such cases into consideration. Alternatively, it could be argued that such cases make it less clear that the specific focus interpretations can be systematically paired with certain construction types (e.g., exhaustivity with preverbal focus in Hungarian). This chapter does not intend to take a stand on this issue. In general, pragmatico-semantic distinctions such as exhaustivity will only be mentioned below where they are directly relevant for the analyses of certain focus constructions (see, e.g., sections 1.3.4 or 4.3.2). More often than not, such distinctions will be ignored and focus will be treated as a unified phenomenon. This is based on the fact that all types of foci satisfy the wh-test, which was argued above to be a characteristic test for focus; all types of foci share a distinctive prosodic marking (main stress or pitch accent); and all types of focus have the discourse status of new or asserted information.

subsection.heading: 1.2.4 Ways of encoding focus in the grammar
subsection.p: The literature on focus is vast. Without any attempt at an exhaustive mention, works that deal with focus and other discourse roles from a semantic perspective include Szabolcsi (1981b), Krifka (1991), Diesing (1992b), Rooth (1992), and Schwarzschild (1999). The prosodic aspect of focus is investigated by Gussenhoven (1984), Selkirk (1984, 1986, 1995), Rochemont (1986), Pierrehumbert and Hirschberg (1990), Hayes and Lahiri (1991), and Cinque (1993). Bosch and Van der Sandt (1999) investigate the issue from a performance perspective.

Let us briefly review the literature on focus in light of some questions related to the nature of the interface between the grammar and discourse: does the grammar (in its wide sense; i.e., including phonology but not pragmatics) determine the focus of an utterance? If so, does the grammar encode focus unambiguously? As we shall see, these questions help us divide the positions available in the literature into two classes: those that argue for encoding focus in the grammar directly, and those that argue for underdeterminacy with respect to grammatical encoding of focus.

There is a wide range of views on the issue of the grammatical representation of focus. The spectrum ranges from the functional sentence perspective (i.e., the Prague School) through the discourse-theoretically motivated works (e.g., Gundel 1974; Prince 1979, 1981; Lambrecht 1994) to the strict ‘encoding’ view of the GB/Minimalist literature.

The Prague School view, at least in its original form (e.g., Dezső 1974; Hajičová and Sgall 1988; Hajičová et al. 1998; and others), did not perceive the representation of focus in the grammar as an issue. For them, discourse notions such as focus and topic were readily available in the grammar itself. Their functionalist and to a large extent descriptivist point of view enabled them to make certain far-reaching generalizations (e.g., the fact that the topic usually precedes the focus, or the tendency for topics to be left-peripheral), and they intended to go no further.

The pragmatic approaches to focus, in particular the different works based on Relevance Theory (Sperber and Wilson 1995; Kempson et al. 2004), advocate a certain underdeterminacy of the grammar with respect to focus. They argue that the focus of an utterance is not fully determined by the syntactic and prosodic make-up of the utterance, although no doubt these contribute to the actual focus.

The GB/Minimalist approaches are the strictest in the sense that they advocate a direct and unambiguous mapping between the grammatical representation of an utterance and its focus. From now on, we will concentrate on these. This is not to say that these approaches would be the only ones that advocate a deterministic encoding of focus in the grammar. There are many proposals, some outside the GB/Minimalist framework, that are not considered here for lack of space. These include King (1993, 1997), Butt and King (1996), Vallduví and Engdahl (1996), Erteschik-Shir (1997), Steedman (2000), and Kempson et al. (2004), among many others.

In the generative literature, the standard view of the late 1980s and early 1990s was and to a large extent still is that focus is directly and unambiguously represented in the syntactic representation (cf. Antinucci and Cinque 1977; Calabrese 1982, 1992b; Abraham and De Meij 1986; Horvath 1986; Rochemont 1986; Rochemont and Culicover 1989; Brody 1990b, 1995a; Kiss 1995b, 1998; Vallduví 1995; Erteschik-Shir 1997; Rizzi 1997; Vallduví and Vilkuna 1998; Zubizarreta 1998). In other words, the syntactic representation of a sentence would provide the necessary information to identify the focus.

In particular, since Jackendoff's (1972) seminal work, the standard way to encode focus in the syntactic representation is by the syntactic (and semantic) feature [+Focus], or [+F] for short: “I suggest the following way, which does minimal violence to the theory as a whole. One artificial construct is required: a syntactic marker F which can be associated with any node in the surface structure” (Jackendoff 1972: 240). [+F] is freely assigned to a constituent, (11), and the F-marked constituent is taken to be the semantic focus of the utterance, by his focus assignment principle, (12):

(11)
[+F] marking:
Mark any constituent as [+F].

(12)
Focus assignment:
The semantic material associated with surface structure nodes dominated by F is the Focus of the sentence. To derive the Presupposition, substitute appropriate semantic variables for the focused material.
(Jackendoff 1972: 240)

Let us illustrate Jackendoff's proposal. In the answer in (2) above, [+F] is assigned to the direct object pizza, which is interpreted as the focal part of the utterance. The presupposition of the utterance can be obtained by replacing the focus with a variable. This is shown in (13):

(13)
a. John ate [F the pizza].
b. Presupposition: John ate x.

As will become clear in the course of this chapter, the idea that focus is encoded in the syntactic representation by means of a syntactic feature, [+Focus], has been fundamental to all GB/Minimalist theories of focus until very recently. 2 It is therefore the most important theoretical assumption in these theories.

subsection.heading: 1.2.5 The focus construction
subsection.p: Focus as a grammatical notion is universal. There are no known languages that would not have a way to signal that a particular constituent is focused. Predominantly, focus is marked by prosodic prominence, more precisely by main stress or pitch accent or (boundary) tones. Morphological focus marking is also available in many languages. Finally, many languages use specific syntactic constructions to indicate discourse functions such as focus. In what follows, the discussion will center on this group. An informal definition of languages that have syntactic focus constructions is given by Kiss (1995b):

(14) The (discourse-)semantic function ‘focus’, expressing identification, is realised through a particular structural relation (in other words, it is associated with a particular structural position). (Kiss 1995: 6)

There are two constructions that arguably fall under this definition, but that are not discussed here: clefts and Heavy NP Shift. Apart from space limitations, the main reason for the omission is that they do not always carry a focus interpretation, although it is true that they often or even predominantly do. The fact that they do not necessarily carry focus interpretation is enough for a claim that they are not really ‘focus constructions’.

This fact is illustrated for clefts first. It is often claimed that the fronted part in a cleft is the focus of the utterance (e.g., Rochemont 1986; Kiss 1998). This is true in the exchange in (15a), but not in the exchange in (15b):

(15)
a. A: I thought you ate the pizza.
B: No, it was the spaghetti I ate.
b. A: I thought it was Peter who ate the pizza.
B: No, it was Peter who ate the spaghetti.

Admittedly, the non-focal clefted phrase is well-formed, because the example in (15b) is echoic. But other cases exist where the clefted phrase does not correspond to the focus of the utterance. In French, as Doetjes et al. (2004) showed, the clefted constituent may only form a part of the focus, rather than be the focus itself. Their examples are given below. In (16), avec plaisir ‘with pleasure’ is not the focus itself. The sentence does not mean that the speaker means to refute a belief that it is not with pleasure that he invites the other one to the seminar. Similarly, (17) does not mean that the person only thanks Nicolas Ruwet and Maurice Gross, but no one else. Rather, as Doetjes et al. argue, these sentences are broad (or wide) focus utterances. So clefting does not serve the need to focus the fronted constituent:

(16)
C’est avec plaisir que je vous invite à participer à ce séminaire.
it/that is with pleasure that I invite you to this seminar

(17)
C’est à Nicolas Ruwet et à Maurice Gross que je dois l’essentiel de ma formation dans cette discipline.
‘It's to Nicolas Ruwet and to Maurice Gross that I owe the essential part of my training in this discipline.’

Heavy NP Shift has similar characteristics. As (18a) illustrates, the rightmost constituent is often the focus of the utterance. However, this is not always the case. First, according to Williams (2003b), Heavy NP Shift is also felicitous as an answer to a question that requires VP focus (see (18b)). Second, the same echoic pattern as above can be also illustrated for Heavy NP Shift, (18c). Finally, as (18d) shows, discourse-linked phrases may also undergo Heavy NP Shift, (18d) (Fritz Newmeyer, p.c.):

(18)
a. A: What did John give to Mary?
B: John gave to Mary all the money in the SATCHEL.
b. A: What did John do?
B: John gave to Mary all the money in the SATCHEL.
c. A: John gave to Joe all the money in the satchel.
B: No, John gave to MARY all the money in the satchel.
d. A: To whom did you give all your books on the phonetic foundations of conventional implicature?
B: I gave to MARY all of those unbelievably ridiculous publications.
In what follows, the discussion will be limited to the cases that fall under a somewhat more restrictive characterization of focus constructions that is given in intuitive terms in (19):

(19)
Focus construction:
A particular structural relation (in other words, a particular structural position) that is associated with the (discourse-)semantic function ‘focus’.

In the next section a description is given of the basic facts concerning the Hungarian focus construction. At the same time, some arguments are put forward based on Horvath's (1986) analysis that the Hungarian focus construction is the result of syntactic movement.

subsection.heading: 1.3 Focus movement in Hungarian: basic data
subsection.p: This section introduces the basic data concerning focus constructions. The facts enumerated here are exemplified by Hungarian, but most of the properties hold in other languages as well. Further characteristics and facts from other languages are introduced in the following sections as they become relevant for the discussion of the various analyses.

subsection.heading: 1.3.1 Preverbal focus in Hungarian
subsection.p: Horvath (1986) gives the following generalization for focus in Hungarian:

(20) A constituent (other than V or a projection of V) can be interpreted as the FOCUS of its clause in Hungarian if, and only if, it itself occupies an immediately pre-verbal position, or is contained in a phrase that does so. (Horvath 1986: 91)

In (21b–c) and (22b–c) it is shown that a focused constituent in Hungarian must appear preverbally. At the same time, as (21a) and (22a) illustrate, the most natural position of both arguments (see 22a) and adjuncts (see 21a) is postverbal, if the constituent is not focused:

(21)
a. Attila félt a földrengéstől.
Attila feared the earthquake-loc
‘Attila was afraid of the earthquake.’
b. Attila a földrengéstől
félt.
Attila the earthquake-loc feared
‘It was the earthquake that Attila was afraid of.’ (Horvath 1986: 91, ex. 1)
c. *Attila félt a földrengéstől.
Attila feared the earthquake-loc
‘It was the earthquake that Attila was afraid of.’ (Horvath 1986: 92, ex. 3)

(22)
a. Mari az asztalra tette az edényeket.
Mari table-loc put the dishes-acc
‘Mari put the dishes on the table.’
b. Mari az edényeket
tette az asztalra.
Mari the dishes-acc put table-loc
‘It was the dishes that Mari put on the table.’ (Horvath 1986: 91, ex. 2)
c. *Mari az asztalra tette az edényeket.
Mari table-loc put the dishes-acc
‘It was the dishes that Mari put on the table.’ (Horvath 1986: 92, ex. 4)
This is also true if a subpart of a DP is focused, as shown in (23): 3

(23)
a. Attila Mari kutyájától félt.
Attila Mari dog-loc feared
b. *Attila félt Mari kutyájától.
Attila feared Mari dog-loc
‘It was Mary's dog that Attila was afraid of.’ (Horvath 1986: 143, fn. 2, ex. i, ii)

subsection.heading: 1.3.2 Scrambling or movement?
subsection.p: Horvath (1986) shows that the focus of an utterance that surfaces in the matrix clause may originate from an embedded clause, even if the embedded clause is finite. This is illustrated for arguments in (24a), and for adjuncts in (24b). (Note that long focus movement is unacceptable for many speakers.)

(24)
a. Annáti
mondta hogy ti jön.
Anna-acc said that comes
‘((S)he) said that Anna was coming.’ (Lipták 1998: 91)
b. Londonbai
mondtad hogy mész ti
London-loc said-you that go-you
‘You said you were going to London’ (Lipták 1998: 92)
As (25) shows, there is no restriction to the number of clauses a focus can cross:

(25)
Annáti
mondtad hogy a szomszédok látták hogy ti jön.
Anna-acc said-you that the neighbors saw that comes
‘You said that the neighbors saw that Anna was coming.’ (modified from Lipták 1998: 92)

This indicates that the focus construction is not clause-bound, which led to the general conclusion that the preverbal focus in Hungarian is the result of movement rather than a case of scrambling. Such so-called long focus movement cases are discussed in Horvath (1986), Kiss (1987, 1998), Lipták (1998), and Gervain (2002).

As Horvath shows, an analysis of the preverbal focus as scrambling is independently ruled out, as scrambling into the higher clause is not well-formed even though the matrix predicate may case-mark and/or agree with the moved element. In other words, long focus movement may only target the preverbal position. This is shown in (26):

(26)
*A gyerekek mondták a földrengéstőli
hogy Attila félt ti.
the kids said the earthquake-loc that Attila feared
‘The kids said that Attila was afraid of the earthquake.’
(Horvath 1986: 100, ex. 19)
As a further indication that focus constructions involve movement, Horvath (1986) showed that long focus movement observes complex NP islands: 4

(27)
*Az elnököti
mondtad hogy hallottad [DP a hírt [CP hogy megérkezett ei]].
the president-acc said-you that heard-you the news-acc that prt-arrived
‘You said you heard the news that the president had arrived.’
(Gervain 2002: 39, ex. 25)
Focus movement observes adjunct islands as well. So focus movement out of an adjunct clause is blocked:

(28)
*Az elnök(öt)i
figyelmeztettek minket [CP hogy meg érkezett ei]].
the president(-acc) warned-they us-acc that prt arrived
‘They warned us that the president arrived.’
(Gervain 2002: 39, ex. 25)

Wh-elements in Hungarian do not occupy the [Spec, CP] position; rather, if they appear in an embedded clause, they follow the complementizer hogy ‘that’. Thus, an intervening wh-element is not expected to block long focus movement. In other words, focus movement is not sensitive to wh-islands: 5

(29)
Az elnököti
mondtad hogy hallottad [CP hogy mikor érkezett meg ti].
the president-acc said-you that heard-you that when arrived prt
‘You said you heard when the president had arrived.’

On the basis of the above data, the Hungarian preverbal focus construction is taken to be a case of focus movement, in the sense that it is a movement operation into a position where the moved element is interpreted as focus.

subsection.heading: 1.3.3 The syntactic position of the focus: adjacency with the verb and complementarity with wh
subsection.p: The two syntactic characteristics that proved to be essential in GB and Minimalist analyses of the Hungarian focus construction are the following: (i) the focused constituent is immediately preverbal; (ii) a wh-element and a focus are in complementary distribution. As we shall now see, the two properties are in fact closely related.

As Horvath (1986) shows, the distribution of adverbs can be used to demonstrate that focus and verb must be adjacent in Hungarian. Sentence adverbs can precede the focus, or follow the verb, but they cannot intervene between focus and verb:

(30)
Mari valószínűleg/hirtelen egy kanál sót *valószínűleg/*hirtelen tett valószínűleg/hirtelen a kávéjába
Mary probably/suddenly a spoonful salt-acc probably/suddenly put probably/suddenly the coffee-her-loc
‘Mary probably/suddenly put a spoonful of salt in her coffee.’
(Horvath 1986: 102, ex. 23)

The same adjacency requirement is also observed with wh-elements. As (31) illustrates, every wh-element (except for miért ‘why’) has to be immediately preverbal. So sentence adverbs can precede the wh-element, or follow the verb, but they cannot intervene between the two:

(31)
Mari ?valószínűleg/?hirtelen mit *valószínűleg/*hirtelen tett ?valószínűleg/hirtelen a kávéjába.
Mary probably/suddenly what-acc probably/suddenly put probably/suddenly the coffee-her-loc
‘What did Mary probably/suddenly put in her coffee?’
(based on Horvath 1986: 102, ex. 23)

The fact that focus and wh both need to occupy an immediately preverbal position explains the complementary distribution between the two. This is illustrated in (32). Ritkán ‘rarely’ requires obligatory focusing, so it cannot appear postverbally (32a–b). This restriction is absent if it appears in a wh-question. In this case the adverb must occur postverbally and the wh-element occupies the immediately preverbal position (32c–f):

(32)
a. Ritkán jár ide.
rarely comes prt-to
b. *Ide jár ritkán.
c. Ki jár ritkán ide?
who comes rarely here-to
‘Who comes here rarely?’
d. *Ki ritkán jár ide?
e. *Ritkán ki jár ide?
f. *Ritkán jár ki ide?

In Hungarian there is a class of elements that are called verbal modifers, which also appear immediately preverbally. This group includes verbal particles (prt), resultatives, depictives, and incorporated prototypical objects that often lack a determiner layer. The immediately preverbal positioning of these is illustrated in (33a–d) respectively:

(33)
a. Mari valószínűleg /hirtelen bele *valószínűleg /*hirtelen tett valószínűleg /hirtelen a kávéjába egy kanál sót.
Mary probably/suddenly prt probably/suddenly put probably/suddenly the coffee- her-loc a spoonful salt-acc
‘Mary probably/suddenly put a spoonful of salt into her coffee.’
b. Mari valószínűleg /hirtelen tönkre *valószínűleg /*hirtelen tette ?valószínűleg /?hirtelen a kávéját egy kanál sóval.
Mary probably/suddenly res-loc probably/suddenly put-def probably/suddenly the coffee- her-acc a spoonful salt-inst
‘Mary probably/suddenly spoilt her coffee with a spoonful of salt.’
c. Mari valószínűleg hidegen *valószínűleg itta valószínűleg a kávéját.
Mary probably cold-loc probably drank-def probably/suddenly the coffee-her-acc
‘Mary probably drank her coffee cold.’
d. Mari valószínűleg kávét *valószínűleg ivott valószínűleg reggel.
Mary probably coffee-acc probably drank probably morning
‘Mary probably drank coffee this morning.’
(based on Horvath 1986: 102, ex. 23)
As expected, verbal modifiers are in complementary distribution with foci (and also with wh). This illustrated for particles in (34):

(34)
Mari *bele egy kanál sót
*bele tett bele a kávéjába.
Mary prt a spoonful salt-acc prt put prt the coffee-her-loc
‘Mary put a spoonful of salt into her coffee.’
(based on Horvath 1986: 102, ex. 23)

As a final characteristic of preverbal focus, Horvath notes that the immediately preverbal position does not admit free right-branching recursion. This is a characteristic left-branch effect in an otherwise right-branching language (see Emonds 1976: 19), which might be indicating that the focus occupies a left-branch position. As (35) shows, the focus position only admits the head of the relative clause, not the clause itself. Vogel and Kenesei (1990) argued that the reason for this restriction is in fact prosodic. It is due to the requirement that the focus and the verb form one phonological phrase. Thus, material that is itself the size of an intonational phrase, such as a relative clause, cannot intervene between the focus and the verb:

(35)
a. *A tanár AZT a gyereket
[CP aki túl sokat beszélt] küldte ki a szobából.
the teacher that-acc the kid-acc who too much-acc talked sent prt the room-loc
b. A tanár AZT a gyereket
küldte ki a szobából [CP aki túl sokat beszélt].
the teacher that-acc the kid-acc sent prt the room-loc who too much-acc talked
‘The teacher sent out of the room the kid that was talking too much.’
(Horvath 1986: 103–4, ex. 24)

subsection.heading: 1.3.4 The semantics of Hungarian preverbal focus
subsection.p: Szabolcsi (1981b) argued that the preverbal focus position in Hungarian is associated with exhaustive listing in such a way that it is directly reflected in the truth-conditions. Thus a sentence like (4a) means something like (4b) (repeated here):

(4)
a. A tanári
Jánosnakj
adott jelest ti tj.
the teacher John-dat gave A+-acc
‘The teacher gave an A+ to John.’ (Kiss 1994: 27, ex. 55)
b. John is the only person amongst the members of the class (or some other set of people who could have gotten A+) that the teacher gave an A+ to.

In other words, there is a focus operator that checks every member of a contextually given relevant set of entities for the property in question (here the property of receiving A+ from the teacher) and identifies John as the single member of that set of whom the property is true.

Szabolcsi (1981b) also demonstrated that focusing has an effect on the truth-conditions of the sentence. For instance, compare (5) and (6) (repeated here). (5b) is a logical consequence of (5a), while this is not true of (6b) and (6a). Consequently, conjoining either (6a) or (6b) with the negation of the other one does not yield a contradiction. This is shown in (7) (repeated here):

(5)
a. Jánosi
magával vitte Marit és Évát ti.
John self-com took Mary-acc and Eva-acc
‘John took Mary and Eva with him.’
b. Jánosi
magával vitte Marit ti.
John self-com took Mary-acc
‘John took Mary with him.’ (Kiss 1994: 28, ex. 59)

(6)
a. Jánosi
[Marit és Évát]j
vitte magával ti tj.
John Mary-acc and Eva-acc took self-com
‘It was Mary and Eva that John took with himself.’
b. Jánosi
Maritj
vitte magával ti tj
John Mary-acc took self-com
‘It was Mary that John took with himself.’ (Kiss 1994: 29, ex. 60)

(7)
a. Jánosi
nem [Marit és Évát]j
vitte magával ti tj
hanem Maritj
vitte magával ti tj.
John not Mary-acc and Eva-acc took self-com but Mary-acc took self-com
‘It was not Mary and Eva but Mary that John took with himself.’
(Kiss 1994: 29, ex. 61)

Recall also, however, that Kiss (1987) points out that exclusion may sometimes be absent from the meaning of focus. In (9), for instance, no exhaustivity requirement is present on the focused element színészek ‘actors’. Rather, the group of people outside reading out loud is simply identified as a group of actors:

(9)
A kertbeni
színészekj
olvasnak fel ti tj.
the garden-loc actors read prt
‘In the garden, actors are reading out loud.’ (based on Kiss 1994: 28, ex. 56)

subsection.heading: 1.4 Summary
subsection.p: This introduction had three aims: (i) to give a working definition of focus and focus construction that is precise enough to delimit the range of phenomena that are under discussion; (ii) to introduce basic data and identify some syntactic and semantic characteristics of the Hungarian focus construction; and (iii) to argue that this construction involves syntactic movement rather than scrambling (or PF movement).

subsection.heading: 2 Focus assignment under government
subsection.p: Armed with the definitions and basic data, we can now turn to the first group of analyses of focus movement: the proposal that focus is assigned under government, like case (this section). First, the original proposal of Horvath (1986) is spelt out (section 2.1). Given that government is known to display directionality effects across languages, both preverbal (section 2.2) and postverbal (section 2.3) focus constructions are analyzed. In the final subsection (section 2.4), several aspects of the proposal are discussed. In particular, it is spelt out that this proposal is committed to the idea that focus, like case, is an S-structure phenomenon (section 2.4.1). Word-order variations and directionality effects found in the world's languages are reviewed in light of the proposal. This seems important, as the proposal assumes that government plays a role in focus assignment, and government is known to display directionality effects with case (section 2.4.2). The morphological aspects of the proposal are discussed in section 2.4.3. Finally, the connection between focus and wh-elements as well as verbal modifiers is explored, paving the way to the discussion of the second group of analyses: those that propose that focus movement is like wh-movement (section 3).

subsection.heading: 2.1 Focus parameter
subsection.p: Horvath (1986) observes that the adjacency requirement on focus and the verb, spelt out in section 1.3.3 above, is not restricted to Hungarian. Rather, in other languages such as Basque and Aghem there is also an adjacency requirement on focus and verb, (36a) and (36b):

(36)
a. Jon aurten
etorri da herri honetara.
Basque
John this year come has this town
‘It is this year that John came to this town.’
(Ortiz de Urbina 1989: 214–215)
b. à m
zí á-fín
bç-k
Aghem
sub P eat friends fufu
‘The friends ate fufu.’ (Horvath 1986: 124)

Another grammatical phenomenon that typically requires adjacency with the verb is case. Thus in English, which is a VO language, the object appears immediately postverbally, while in Turkish, an OV language, indefinites, which lack morphological case marking, appear immediately preverbally, (37a) and (37b):

(37)
a. John ate (*pensively) the sandwich.
b. Üc cocuk ücü yeni bir araba (*din) almis. Turkish
three child three new a car yesterday bought
‘Three children bought three new cars.’

Moreover, it turns out that the order of the verb and the focus follows the directionality of government for case in the language. Thus in Basque, which is an OV language, the focus appears immediately to the left of the V, while in Aghem, which is a VO language, the focus is immediately postverbal. For this reason Horvath proposed that in languages with syntactic focus constructions, the syntactic feature FOCUS is assigned by the verb under government, while in languages where syntactic focus constructions are missing FOCUS is assigned freely at S-structure. Thus she formulated the FOCUS parameter:

(38)
FOCUS parameter:
i. FOCUS can be freely assigned to categories in S-structure.
ii. FOCUS is a syntactic feature inherent to the lexical category V. It can be assigned to other categories by the V under government and adjacency.
(modified from Horvath 1986: 132)

It is hard to overemphasize the importance of this proposal. By establishing a parallel between case and syntactic focus constructions, Horvath (1986) provided a way to handle the phenomenon of syntactic focus marking. The similarities of case and focus were compelling. Both are subject to the same government-under-adjacency requirement that was fundamental to GB theory. Consequently, languages with focus constructions received a convincing analysis: focus can be treated similarly to case.

The consequences of Horvath's work, both empirical and theoretical, are far-reaching. For instance, they are at least partially responsible for the birth of a whole enterprise of analyses of focus constructions in different languages, culminating in the collection of papers edited by Kiss (1995b) and Rebuschi and Tuller (1999). The details of two of these will be fleshed out here: Horvath's own analysis of Hungarian (section 2.2) and Tuller's (1992) analysis of the Chadic languages (section 2.3). The choice is motivated by the fact that Hungarian has preverbal focus, while the Chadic languages discussed here have postverbal focus constructions.

subsection.heading: 2.2 Preverbal focus languages: Hungarian
subsection.p: Recall from section 1.3.3 that Horvath (1986) showed that in Hungarian focused constituents, wh-elements, and verbal modifiers are in complementary distribution. The relevant data are repeated here for convenience. If a focused constituent or a wh-element is present in the clause, it appears immediately preverbally. The verbal modifier is postverbal in this case. If there is no wh-element or focused constituent in the clause, the verbal modifier is immediately preverbal:

(39)
Mari hirtelen egy kanál sót/mit/bele *hirtelen tett hirtelen (bele) a kávéjába.
Mary suddenly a spoonful salt-acc/what-acc/prt suddenly put suddenly prt the coffee-her-loc
‘Mary suddenly put a spoonful of salt/what in(to) her coffee.’

To put it differently, wh-elements, focused constituents, and verbal modifiers all appear in the immediately preverbal position. Thus, they are in complementary distribution (see section 1.3.3 for precise data). Horvath argues that this is due to the fact that they literally appear in the same syntactic position. If one occupies this position, neither of the others can appear there. In other words, she proposes that focused constituents (as well as verbal modifiers and wh-elements) move to an immediately preverbal position:

This allows the verb to govern the preposed constituents, which Horvath claims is necessary for foci according to the proposed FOCUS parameter (see 38 above). She proposes that wh-elements target the same position because they are subject to a universal constraint regarding their distribution:

(41) The syntactic position(s) in which non-echo interrogative wh-phrases can appear in a language L will be identical to or be a proper subset of the positions in which FOCUS-constituents can appear in a language L.
(Horvath 1986: 122)

subsection.heading: 2.3 Postverbal focus languages: Chadic languages
subsection.p: Horvath's (1986) idea that the adjacency requirement between the V and the focus is the result of the requirement that the V governs the focus makes strong predictions for cross-linguistic variation. Languages like Basque, Turkish, Hindi, and Urdu are strict SOV languages, so presumably the direction of government in these languages is to the left. Thus, the prediction is that if these languages have focus constructions, then focus will be immediately preverbal. This is indeed the case, as has been argued among others by Ortiz de Urbina (1995) for Basque, by Kural (1992) for Turkish, and by Butt and King (1996) and Kidwai (1999) for Hindi-Urdu. On the other hand, typical VO languages, where the direction of government is to the right, are expected to have focus constituents in an immediately postverbal position. There are a number of languages that show this pattern. This possibility will be illustrated here by reproducing Tuller's (1992) analysis of Chadic languages.

Tuller (1992) presents an analysis of focus constructions in Chadic languages, which is very close to Horvath's (1986) analysis in spirit. Tuller argues that [+FOCUS] is a feature of Infl and that the focused constituent needs to be in the governing domain of Infl. In the languages she discusses (Western Bade, Podoko, Tangale, Kanakuru, and Ngizim), the direction of government is to the right, as in English. She argues that in these languages, the V moves to Infl, while the focused constituent adjoins to the VP from the left. As a result, we get a configuration where focus is postverbal and adjacent to the verb and is in the governing domain of the verb in an ECM fashion. This is illustrated schematically in (42):

The languages under discussion fall into two groups depending on a more precise characterization of their focus constructions. In Type A languages, the focus is directly adjacent to the V from the right. Western Bade and Podoko are languages of this kind. In Type B languages, the head of the direct object or the entire direct object intervenes between the V and the focus on its right. This group includes languages like Tangale, Ngizim, and Kanakuru. Tuller notes that all the Type B languages are SVO and that Type A languages are either SVO or VSO. She argues that this is not an accident; rather, what distinguishes Type A languages from Type B languages is that the trace of the V that undergoes V-movement to I is able to govern (for case purposes) a VP-internal direct object in Type A languages, but not in Type B.

Given the schema in (42), Type B languages face a difficulty. V-to-I movement is necessary to license the focus in the governing domain of Infl. At the same time, since the trace of the verb is unable to govern a VP-internal object, V-to-I movement is not possible, as the direct object would remain caseless. Tuller arges that the head of the direct object incorporates into the V prior to V-to-I, thus bypassing the case problem. Indeed, as the following example shows, in Kanakuru, the head of a complex NP intervenes between the V and the focus, but the relative clause has to follow the focus. This phenomenon is called direct object splitting:

(43)
Ad′e [shiruwoi] eng gadlai
[m
shee wura] ane. Kanakuru
ate fish-the cat-the RM she fried up
‘The cat ate up the fish that she fried.’ (Tuller 1992: 309, ex. 9a)

But in Tangale and Ngizim, there seems to be optionality with respect to the size of the intervening object. The head or the entire object may intervene. See (44) for a Tangale example. This is unexpected: how could the whole complex NP incorporate into the V? Incorporation usually only affects heads, not complex phrases:

(44)
Shag [wamunjaanan] n
eng [nam Aisha d′ik
]? Tangale
ate food-RM who RM Aisha prepared
‘Who ate the food that Aisha prepared?’
b. shag [wamunjaanan Aisha d′ik
n] n
eng
(Tuller 1992: 310, ex. 10)

Tuller offers an elegant solution to the problem. She observes that in all the examples where an entire object intervenes between the V and the focus, the focus is in fact clause-final. So she argues, Tangale and Ngizim have a separate focus construction, one that places the focused constituent in a right-peripheral specifier in the complementizer domain. So the optionality of direct object splitting is merely epiphenomenal. What really happens is that direct object splitting (i.e., incorporation of the head of the direct object into the V) is obligatory in these languages as well, but this can be masked by the presence of an alternative construction that places focus in a right-peripheral, clause-final position.

As a final point, Tuller explains why Kanakuru, the language where the obligatoriness of object splitting is transparent, lacks the clause-final focus position. The answer is simple: it has a clause-initial focus position instead. See (45):

(45)
Basha
shee tupa ya. Kanakuru
foc 2perf V DO
‘Basha sent him.’ (Tuller 1992: 324, ex. 28a)

subsection.heading: 2.4 Focus and case: discussion
subsection.p: So far, analyses of both postverbal and preverbal focus constructions have been sketched. It was shown that Horvath's focus parameter goes a long way toward accounting for the data. In languages with focus movement, the focus moves to a position governed by Infl. Thus the directionality of focus movement follows the directionality of government in the language. Apart from the empirical explanatory value, the theoretical significance of this work is also remarkable in several respects. The discussion of the theoretical implications of this proposal is the topic of this section.

subsection.heading: 2.4.1 D-structure or S-structure?
subsection.p: First, Horvath's theory provides further support for the position argued for by Chomsky (1971) that focus is established at S-structure, rather than at D-structure or at PF. Case is the prototypical example of an S-structure phenomenon in GB theory. So, by drawing a parallel between case and focus, Horvath emphasizes the S-structure characteristics of focus. Chomsky (1971) and Jackendoff (1972) argued that focus cannot be a D-structure phenomenon as previously assumed, since focused constituents can be created at S-structure that were not available at D-structure. An example is given in (46). Here the underlying D-structure of (46a) is given in (46b). If focus was determined at D-structure, then we would expect that the focus of the utterance would be as in (46c). So (46d) would be a possible answer to (46a). However, as (46e) indicates, (46d) is not the only possible answer that can be given, and thus (46c) is not the only possible focus of the utterance in (46a); (46f) is also a possible focus:

(46)
a. Was it a red-shirted EX-CONVICT that he was warned to look out for?
b. the one he was warned to look out for was X
c. a red-shirted ex-convict
d. No, he was warned to look out for an AUTOMOBILE SALESMAN.
e. No, he was warned to look out for a red-shirted AUTOMOBILE SALESMAN.
f. ex-convict

Chomsky argues that the potential foci of the utterance in (46a), which are [N ex-convict] and [NP a red-shirted ex-convict], are not available at the D-structure representation; rather they are distinguished by the prosody of the utterance: any constituent at S-structure that contains the main stress of the utterance is a potential focus of the utterance.

In another example, Chomsky shows that in certain cases, the S-structure focus of an utterance does not even correspond to a constituent in D-structure. The utterance in (47a) can be felicitously answered by any of the utterances in (47b–d). Presumably the D-structure representation of (47a) is (47e). If so, then the focus indicated in (47c), [VP likely not even to be nominated], corresponds to the string certain to lose, which is not a constituent at D-structure in (47e):

(47)
a. Is John certain to WIN?
b. No, John is certain to LOSE.
c. No, John is likely not even to be NOMINATED.
d. No, the election will never take PLACE.
e. [John win] is certain

So focus in English is an S-structure phenomenon. Then an analysis, such as Horvath's, that argues that the syntax of focus constructions is similar to the syntax of case is a welcome one, given that case is an S-structure phenomenon as well.

subsection.heading: 2.4.2 Focus, case, and word order universals
subsection.p: Another advantage of Horvath's proposal is that by providing a parameter of available options for UG, the proposal has a strong predictive power. Languages are not expected to have focus positions such as ‘second constituent on the right of the verb’ or ‘penultimate constituent preceding the verb’, which are not attested. It is expected that languages where the direction of government is to the left will have preverbal, rather than postverbal, focus constructions. And vice versa: languages where the direction of government is to the right are expected to have postverbal focus constructions. There are exceptions to this generalization. For instance, it is certainly controversial to claim that Hungarian, which has a preverbal focus construction, would be an OV language (but see Marácz 1989 and Ackema 2004 for proposals along this line). 6

Nevertheless, the parallelism with case is quite compelling. This is especially clear in Tuller's analysis of Chadic languages. There it seems that a direct object that requires adjacency to the V for case reasons, and a focus that also requires adjacency to the verb, may even ‘compete’ for this position in a way that is similar to phenomena involving more than one object requiring case. For instance, in their analysis of double object constructions, Neeleman and Weerman (1999) argued that in double object constructions, where two NPs need to be case-marked by the verb, movement of the verb and VP-shell formation is necessary to provide a second position that is right-adjacent to and therefore governed by the verb.

There is another aspect of the relationship between case and focus that is relevant here, and it is for this reason, too, that Tuller's analysis of the Chadic languages is important. It is a wide-spread belief among linguists, although one that is not often rigorously argued for, that some kind of a functionalist explanation is ultimately right for the well-known and by no means absolute generalization that languages that have rich morphological case systems have free word order. To be more precise, the line of thought would go as follows: if a language marks argument relations by case morphology, then syntactic positions need not mark grammatical functions; rather they mark discourse functions. Hence topic and focus constructions are expected in languages with an elaborate system of morphological argument marking (either in the form of case markers on the arguments or in the form of head-marking on the V). Hungarian, Basque, and Turkish are textbook examples for this claim.

But the generalization is not absolute. For instance, the Chadic languages that Tuller discusses are clear counter-examples to the claim. These languages have strict SVO or VSO/SVO word order. They are by no means free-word-order, non-configurational languages. Nevertheless, they have grammaticalized focus constructions. Furthermore, they are counter-examples to the claim that syntactic discourse function marking necessarily means the presence of morphological argument structure marking. These languages also lack a rich case or head-marking paradigm. An in-depth study of such counter-examples would be enlightening for a formal account of the interactions of morphological and syntactic marking of argument structure and discourse functions.

subsection.heading: 2.4.3 Focus, case, and morphology
subsection.p: As far as case and focus are concerned, there is also room for establishing morphological parallelism. If syntactic focus constructions are similar to syntactic case assignment, then it is suggestive that one could find the equivalent of morphological case marking as well. There are many proposals in the literature that identify focus particles that attach to focused constituents in a similar way to that in which morphological case markers attach to NPs. (See the discussion on Somali in section 3.5.3 for a potential example for a morphologically overt focus head.) This, however, only shows that both case and focus can be marked by means of morhological markers. But this is true of many other things, such as tense and aspect. A real parallel would have to be established between morphological case marking and focus particles.

A case that might be interesting to study from this perspective is Japanese and Korean. 7 In Japanese, Vermeulen (2005) argued that the nominative marker -ga is actually a focus marker when it appears on adjuncts in the so-called multiple nominative construction. In Korean, if an object is contrastively focused, the object-marker -lul/-ul is replaced by the contrastive focus marker -nun/-un, which bears main stress. The subject marker -ka/-i can be replaced by the topic marker -nun/-un. The complementary distribution of the morphological markers suggest that they somehow belong to the same class of morphological markers. This is illustrated in (48):

(48)
a. Swuni-ka hakkyo-eyse Chelswu-lul manna-ss-ta. Korean
Swuni-sub school-at Chelswu-obj meet-pst-M
‘Swuni met Chelswu at school.’
b. Chelswu-nun ku chayk-un
sa-ss-ta.
Chelswu-top the book-con buy-pst-m
‘Chelswu bought the book.’
(Choe 1995: 271, ex. 2a; 285, ex. 35a)

subsection.heading: 2.4.4 Focus, verbal modifiers, and wh
subsection.p: Horvath (1986) showed that in Hungarian, focused constituents, wh-elements, and verbal modifiers are in complementary distribution. They all appear immediately preverbally. She argued that the reason for the complementary distribution is that they literally occupy the same syntactic position.

However, Brody (1990b) challenged this view and argued that this reasoning only applies to focused constituents and wh-elements. The complementary distribution between verbal modifiers and foci (or wh) is not due to the fact that they occupy the same position. Rather, he proposed that verbal modifiers bear a semantically and lexically close relationship to the verb. Resultatives and verbal particles arguably form complex verbs with the V, and have common theta-grids. This idea has been formulated by Ackerman (1984), who argued that verbal modifiers are base generated in an immediately preverbal position:

In contrast, Brody argued, focus and wh-elements are different: they occupy a preverbal position as a result of movement of both the focal element and the V. The analysis is based on similar data from V2 languages like Dutch. Under V2, the verb moves to C. If it has a particle, which is a subclass of verbal modifiers, the particle is stranded in the VP (Koster 1975). The data in (50) illustrate the analysis: the focused element (or the wh-element) moves to the specifier of a functional head, while the verb adjoins to this head, leaving the particle behind: 8

The main argument in favor of Brody's (1990b) proposal is that focused phrases (or wh-elements) and verbal modifiers are not incompatible. They can occur in one clause, but in this case the verbal modifier is obligatorily postverbal. By assuming that verb movement takes place in clauses with focused constituents or wh-phrases, Brody can maintain a uniform analysis for the position of verbal modifiers in the sense that these are always adjoined to the base position of the verb. In contrast, Horvath has to assume that the position of the verbal modifier is different in clauses with or without a focus (or a wh-element). A further argument in favor of Brody's approach is the syntactic and semantic similarities between focus and wh that are not, or at best partially, shared by verbal modifiers. These similarities between wh and focus will be the subject of the discussion in section 3.

subsection.heading: 3 Focus movement is like wh-movement
subsection.p: The idea that focus is similar to wh rests on both syntactic and semantic considerations that draw a parallel between the two (section 3.2). These considerations gave rise to analyses arguing for the Focus criterion alongside the Wh-criterion, which state that a focus or wh-element has to be licensed in a specifier–head relationship with its licensing head. This proposal is illustrated here by the discussion of Ortiz de Urbina's (1995) analysis of focus movement in Basque (section 3.3). Another, highly influential, proposal, in Rizzi (1997), concerns focus movement in Italian. The innovation here is that the licensing head is no longer Infl or C, but rather a designated functional head, the Focus head (section 3.4). This line of analysis is evaluated in section 3.5. Here the notion is discussed that adjacency effects and the presence of pied-piping give support to an analysis of focus movement based on wh-movement, as the latter also exhibits both adjacency effects and pied-piping (sections 3.5.1–3.5.2). It would be a strong support for Rizzi's line of thinking if a language with an overt Focus head could be identified. The case of Somali is examined from this perspective, with, however, an inconclusive outcome (section 3.5.3). Finally, an alternative, discourse-based explanation is provided for the alleged weak crossover violations described in section 3.1, which are fundamental to the idea that focus involves movement similar to wh-movement (section 3.5.4). By calling into question the parallel between focus movement and wh-movement, the discussion in section 3.5.4 shakes the foundations of the proposal that regards focus movement and wh-movement as essentially similar.

subsection.heading: 3.1 The origins of a movement analysis
subsection.p: Before we embark on a trip to discover the characteristics of focus movement that assimilate it to wh-movement, let us take a step back and investigate the origins of a movement approach to focus. The idea that focus would be associated with movement stems from two independent factors: (i) the fact that focus is quantificational, and (ii) the assumption that quantificational elements take their respective scopes via quantifier raising (May 1977). Let us take these in turn.

subsection.heading: 3.1.1 Focus is quantificational
subsection.p: The fact that focus is quantificational can be illustrated by the examples in (51), where (51a) is true while (51b) is false in the context in (51c), even though (51a) and (51b) differ only in focus. In other words, two sentences may differ in truth-value if they only differ in focus:

(51)
a. John only gave a book to SUE. True
b. John only gave a BOOK to Sue. False
c. John gave a book and a pen to Sue. He gave nothing else to anybody.

As Szabolcsi (1981b) argued, in Hungarian, where overt focus movement takes place, the effect on the truth-value can be observed even without the presence of a focus-sensitive operator such as only. So it is really the focal difference that is responsible for the truth-conditional effect. The Hungarian equivalent of (51) is given in (52) (see also the discussion in section 1.3):

(52)
a. Jánosi
[ZSUZSINAK]j
adott ti tj
egy könyvet. True
John Sue-dat gave a book-acc
‘It was to Sue that John gave a book.’
b. Jánosi
[egy KÖNYVET]j
adott ti tj
Zsuzsinak. False
John a book-acc gave Sue-dat
‘It was a book that John gave to Sue.’
c. Jánosi
adott ti
egy könyvet és egy tollat Zsuzsinak. Nem adott semmi mást senkinek.
John gave a book-acc and a pen-acc Sue-dat not gave nothing else-acc nobody-dat
‘John gave a book and a pen to Sue. He gave nothing else to anybody.’

subsection.heading: 3.1.2 Weak crossover
subsection.p: The treatment of focus in terms of ‘quantifier raising’ was first suggested by Chomsky (1976), who noted that backward coreference is ruled out if the full DP is focused, while allowed if not. Thus (53b), as opposed to (53a), is ungrammatical:

(53)
a. The man that shei met LIKED Maryi.
b. *The man that shei met liked MARY i.
LF: MARY i [the man that shei met liked ti]

Chomsky (1976) argued that the ungrammaticality of (53b) can be explained if one assumes that the focal element undergoes fronting at LF. (53b) is a weak crossover violation resulting from the LF movement of the focused element over the co-indexed pronoun. Thus (53b) is similar to (54a), where the movement of the wh-element across a co-indexed pronoun is ruled out as a weak crossover violation. Note that this argument is considerably weakened by the observation, already made by Jackendoff (1972), that focus disregards syntactic islands. This is illustrated in (54b) for a complex NP island:

(54)
a. *Whoi does the man that shei met like ti?
b. Sam only saw a [NP man [CP who was wearing a RED hat]].

This would mean that focus movement (or maybe LF movement in general) is different from overt movement in that it is not sensitive to islands. This would be an undesirable outcome, especially in light of the facts given in section 1.3.3 that showed that islands are observed by focus movement in languages with focus constructions, like Hungarian. Nevertheless, at least until the early 1990s the alleged weak crossover violation exemplified in (53) was taken to be the strongest argument for the treatment of focus in terms of movement even in languages like English. An evaluation of the strength of this argument will be given in section 3.5.4, where it is shown that (53b) should be analyzed as a discourse violation rather than a violation of the conditions on variable binding.

subsection.heading: 3.2.1 Semantic parallelism
subsection.p: An immediate advantage of treating the syntax of focus and wh in a similar fashion is the following. While it is unclear what would constitute semantic parallelism between focus and case, focus and wh appear to behave in a similar way semantically. Following Jackendoff (1972), we may represent the non-focal part of an utterance by replacing the focus with an appropriate semantic variable, which is existentially bound, as in (55b). Argueably, the wh-question in (55c) carries the same presupposition. In a negative answer to a wh-question, such as (55d), the presupposition is denied. 9 In other words, what we see is that both focal and wh-utterances contain a presupposition. This is partly why a wh-test is so appropriate for identifying foci. The wh-question provides the necessary presupposition for us, and thus it is easy to identify the focus of the answer: it is the part of the answer that is not contained in the presupposition:

(55)
a. It is the man in the red HAT that John saw.
b. ∃x (John saw x)
c. Who did John see?
d. No one. ¬∃x (John saw x)

subsection.heading: 3.2.2 Syntactic parallelism
subsection.p: It has long been noted that focus in languages like Hungarian behaves similarly to wh-elements. 10 In particular, recall from section 1.3.3 (and also sections 2.2 and 2.4) that Hungarian focus movement is in complementary distribution with wh-movement in simple clauses, suggesting that the focus element and the wh-constituent occupy the same surface syntactic position (e.g., Horvath 1986).

Another similarity between focus movement and wh-movement is that both may apply successive-cyclically and thus across finite clauses. As was shown in section 1.3.3, Hungarian has long focus movement of the relevant sort. (In section 3.3 we will see examples of long focus movement in Basque.)

A final property of focus movement that is also displayed by wh-movement is that it licenses parasitic gaps. This is illustrated for Hungarian in (56): (56a, b) show that wh-movement and focus movement license parastic gaps, while (56c, d) show that scrambling or topic movement do not:

(56)
a. Miti
dobott ki Péter ti
anélkül hogy elolvasott volna ti?
what-acc threw prt Peter without that prt-read be-irreal
‘What did Peter file without reading?’
b. Fontos iratokati
dobott ki Péter ti
anélkül hogy elolvasott volna ti.
important documents-acc threw prt Peter without that prt-read be-irreal
‘It was important documents that Peter filed without reading.’
c. Kidobott fontos iratokati
Péter ti
anélkül hogy elolvasott volna ti.
threw-prt important documents-acc Peter without that prt-read be-irreal
‘Peter filed important documents without reading (them).’
d. *Fontos iratokat Péteri
dobott ki anélkül hogy elolvasott volna ti.
important documents-acc Peter threw prt without that prt-read be-irreal
‘Peter filed important documents without reading (them).’

subsection.heading: 3.3 Focus criterion: Basque
subsection.p: The analysis of focus as an instance of A-bar movement, similar to wh-movement, will be illustrated by Basque. Basque is an OV language (Ortiz de Urbina 1989). It is (split) ergative and has morphological case. It has no morphological focus markers, but just as in Hungarian, focused constituents appear in the immediately preverbal position:

(57)
a. Jon herri honetara aurten etorri da.
John this town this year come has
‘John came this year to this town.’
b. Jon AURTEN etorri da herri honetara.
‘It is this year that John came to this town.’
(Ortiz de Urbina 1989: 214–215)

Ortiz de Urbina (1989, 1995) argues that clauses that have a focused constituent instantiate residual V2 effects. Thus in these cases the focused constituent is clause-initial and the V follows immediately. In this respect focus constituents are parallel to wh-words. For this reason, Ortiz de Urbina (1995) proposes an analysis following Rizzi's (1996) Wh-criterion, given in (58):
(58) Wh-criterion:

row.entry: A wh-operator must be in a spec–head configuration with an X0[+wh].
An X0[+wh] must be in a spec–head configuration with an wh-operator.

subsection.p: Rizzi's proposal was meant to capture the fact that (i) wh-questions in English are residual cases of V2; (ii) in multiple wh-questions only one wh-element moves overtly. (i) is ensured if it is assumed that (A) applies at S-structure in English. Languages are parameterized with respect to the level of representation where (B) applies. In English multiple wh-questions, only one wh-element moves to [Spec, CP] overtly; the remaining wh-elements move there at LF. So, in English, (A) applies at S-structure, while (B) applies at LF. 11

In Basque, just as in Hungarian, a focused phrase appears in the specifier of a head bearing a focus feature at S-structure. Any further focused phrases move there at LF. Brody (1990b) and Ortiz de Urbina (1995) proposed the analysis in (59a). What happens in clauses containing a focused constituent and in wh-questions in Basque is that the focus or the wh-element moves to the specifier of C to check the [+wh] or the [+F] feature of C. (So in Basque, the Focus/Wh-criterion applies for both wh-words and focus constituents.) Since C itself does not contain a matching feature, Infl has to raise to C to provide the necessary [+wh] or [+F] feature. This is illustrated schematically in (59b):

(59)
a. Focus criterion:
At S-structure and LF the specifier of a X0[+F] must contain a [+F] phrase.
At LF all [+F] phrases must be in the X0[+wh] must be in a spec–head configuration with a wh-operator.
(modified from Brody 1990: 208)
b. [CPwh[+wh]/focus[+F][C Infl[+wh]/[ +F] C] [+wh]/[+F][IP [I’tInflVP]]]

To be precise, the picture is slightly more complicated. Although in the northern dialects of Basque, the focused constituent may optionally be followed by the inflected auxiliary, with the V remaining in clause-final position, this is not the case in the southern dialects (compare 60b and 60c). In the southern dialects, the V-Aux complex follows the focused constituent, even in the case of periphrastic forms and, unlike in Italian, nothing can intervene between the auxiliary and a verb. The pattern in the northern dialects is similar to the pattern found in V2 constructions, for instance, in Dutch, so it is explained by the Focus criterion. As Ortiz de Urbina (1995) proposed, the pattern in the southern dialects can be accounted for if it is assumed that in addition to I to C movement the V moves to I and the whole V-I complex moves to C:

(60)
a. Jonek liburua irakurri du.
John book read has
‘John has read the book.’
b.
JONEK irakurri du liburura.
c.
JONEK du liburua irakurri
‘It is John that has read this book.’ (Ortiz de Urbina 1995: 200)
The language also displays V1 patterns. As expected, these show up in two cases: as an instance of yes/no questions (61a) and as an instance of what Ortiz de Urbina calls ‘verbal focalization’ (61b):

(61)
a. Irakurri du Jonek liburua?
read has John book
‘Has John read the book?’
b. Hil
da gure ata.
die has our father
‘Our father has died.’
‘Our father did die.’ (Ortiz de Urbina 1995: 110, ex. 22, 23a)
Ortiz de Urbina claims that this is an instance of movement of the Aux-V complex to C triggered by the [+Q]-feature of C in (61a) and triggered by [+F]-feature on C in (61b).

Note that the northern dialects present a partial problem in the V1 case. In these dialects, the Auxiliary does not have to cliticize onto the V, so it is expected that it is the Auxiliary alone that moves to C in yes/no questions or cases of verb focalization. However, as illustrated in (62a) and (62b) respectively, Aux focalization is grammatical, but yes/no questions are deviant:

(62)
a. ba-dut . . . ikusi
ba-aux seen
‘I have seen . . .’
b. ??baduzu . . . ikusi
ba-aux seen
‘Have you seen . . . ?’
(Ortiz de Urbina 1995: 112, ex. 30a, 31a)

To conclude, Ortiz de Urbina (1995) argued that the focus construction in Basque is similar to the wh-construction. They both involve A-bar movement to [Spec, CP], therefore they both instantiate residual V2 (and V1) effects. 12

Similar proposals have been put forward for many languages. Svolaccia et al. (1995) argue that in Somali, [+F] is a feature of C. (See section 3.5.3 for discussion.) The same was proposed by Vilkuna (1994) for Finnish and by King (1993) for Russian. There are also proposals to the effect that [+F] is on I and that therefore [Spec, IP] is the position targeted by focus movement. Aissen (1992) argued that this is the case in some Mayan languages, for example Tzotzil. A review of the syntactic options available for focus constructions is given by Kenesei (1998).

subsection.heading: 3.4 Focus as a functional head: Italian
3.4.1 The Focus head
subsection.p: In the spirit of Pollock's (1989) proposal, in the course of the 1990s it became more and more generally assumed that a separate functional head, Focus, is projected in the left periphery of the clause. The focused element moves to the specifier of the Focus head to check features in a spec–head configuration. An abstract schema is given in (63):

(63)
[FP
XPfocus
F . . . [VPV_tXP]
[+F] [+F]

This was proposed for many languages, with the only differences being the location of Focus with respect to other heads, and whether the movement of the focused constituent (and of the V) is overt or covert. To mention a few: Brody (1995a) on Hungarian; Laka (1990) on Basque; Ouhalla (1994) on Standard Arabic; and many works in Kiss (1995b) and Rebuschi and Tuller (1999), including accounts for Greek (Tsimpli 1995), Korean (Choe 1995), Western Romance languages (Uriagereka 1995b), and Portuguese (Ambar 1999).

In Hungarian, the Focus head is located in the left periphery of the clause (Brody 1995a, among many others). If the Focus head is strong, as it is in Hungarian, it will trigger overt movement of the constituent bearing [+F]. In a tensed sentence, this is accompanied by V movement to F, thus the focused constituent and the V are adjacent. As already mentioned in section 2.2, the main data supporting V-movement are sentences that contain verbal particles. In Hungarian the default position for particles is preverbal; it is immediately in front of the V. In sentences which have a focused element, the particle follows the verb. Brody (1995a) takes this to be an indication of V-movement. This is illustrated in (64):
If the Focus head is weak, as it is in the English, the focused constituent will remain in situ (at least in the overt syntax). 13 This is illustrated in (65):

Rizzi (1997) proposed a similar analysis for the so-called left-peripheral focus in Italian. He argued that the complementizer field in Italian is split in a way that is similar to the proposal about the tense field by Pollock (1989). The topmost complementizer-like head is Force and the lowermost is Finiteness. Topic positions and a unique Focus position are sandwiched between the two. This is shown in the schema in (66):
(66) . . . Force . . . *Topic . . . Focus . . . *Topic . . . Fin . . . IP (* indicates possibility of recursion) (modified from Rizzi 1997, ex. 38)

Movement into the specifier of the Focus head is subject to the Focus criterion, which says that movement is ‘last resort’ and that it only happens to satisfy LF requirements of the element. In particular, a focal element needs to be in a specifier–head configuration with the Focus head at LF (Rizzi 1997: 6).

subsection.heading: 3.4.2 Five characteristics of focus in Italian
subsection.p: Rizzi (1997: 8–9) enumerates a number of properties that characterize foci, as opposed to topics. First, topics, but not foci, allow the presence of resumptive clitics:

(67)
a. Il tuo libro, lo ho comprato.
‘Your book, I bought it.’
b. Il tuo libro ho comprato(, non il suo).
c. *Il tuo libro lo ho comprato(, non il suo).
Focus gives rise to weak crossover violations, while topics do not:

(68)
a. Giannii, suai madre lo sempre apprezzato.
b. ??Giannii suai madre ha sempre apprezzato.
‘Gianni his mother always appreciated, not Pietro.’
(Rizzi 1997: ex. 17, 18)
Bare quantificational elements are felicitous foci, but they cannot be topics:

(69)
a. *Nessuno, lo ho visto.
‘No one, I saw him.’
b. Nessuno ho visto t.
‘I saw no one.’
(Rizzi 1997: ex. 19a, 20a)
There is no restriction on the number of topics that can appear in a clause, while each clause allows only one focus:

(70)
a. Il libro, a Gianni, domani, glielo daro senza’ltro.
‘The book, to John, tomorrow, I’ll give it to him for sure.’
b. *Il libro a Gianni daro senza’ltro (non a Piero, l’articolo).
‘The book to John I’ll give, not to Piero, the article.’
(Rizzi 1997: ex. 21, 22)
Finally, topics, but not foci are compatible with a clause-mate wh-word:

(71)
a. A Gianni, che cosa gli hai detto?
‘To John, what did you tell him?’
b. *A Gianni che cosa hai detto (non a Piero)?
‘To John what did you say, not to Piero?’ (Rizzi 1997: ex. 24a, 25a)

Let us start with the last property of foci, i.e., that they are incompatible with wh-elements. Similarly to Horvath (1986) and Brody (1990b), Rizzi (1997) suggests that focus and wh are incompatible because they are in complementary distribution. In other words, they target the same position.

Rizzi (1997) argues that the first three properties follow from the assumption that focus is quantificational, while topic is not.
