In particular, he suggests that the LF representation of focus movement results in a configuration where a quantifier binds a variable, while the LF representation of the topic construction is different. Here there is A-bar binding of a null constant, by a null operator:

(72)
a. ?* Whoi does hisi mother really like ti (= vbl)?
b. John, whoi hisi mother really likes ti (= nc) . . . (Rizzi 1997: ex. 26)

This characterization of the data would explain why focus gives rise to weak crossover violations, as these are due to semantic variable chains, absent in the case of topics. It would also explain why bare quantificational elements are not possible topics. This is because topic constructions do not provide a variable for the bare quantificational element to bind. Finally, the presence of an overt clitic in the topic constructions disallows the formation of a quantificational chain on the assumptions that quantificational chains bind variables and that overt pronominal clitics are different from traces in this respect: unlike traces, clitics do not license the presence of a variable in the LF representation.

So three seemingly independent generalizations receive a unified explanation. But there is reason to doubt that all three characteristics are a consequence of the proposed quantificational vs. non-quantificational distinction between focus chains and topic chains. The fact that quantificational elements are unlikely topics, the third characteristic difference between focus and topics, also follows from discourse-oriented considerations. Topics, by definition, are referential expressions (Reinhart 1981). So quantificational elements are unlikely topics. To be precise, they are possible topics if and only if they “can be interpreted (pragmatically) as denoting sets” (Reinhart 1981: 65). This possibility is obviously not available for bare quantifiers, but a set denotation can be facilitated by the presence of a lexical restriction. As Rizzi himself notes, quantificational elements with lexical restrictions are much better as topics:

(73)
a. Tutto, lo concosco veramente bene.
‘Everything, I know it really well.’
b. Tutti i tuoi libri, li ho rimessi a posto.
‘All your books, I put them back.’ (Rizzi 1997: ex. 34c)

Let us now turn to the explanation Rizzi offers for the fourth characteristic property of focus in Italian: uniqueness. There can be any number of topics in a clause, but each clause allows a unique focus. He offers an analysis based on the idea, going back to Jackendoff (1972), that the focus of an utterance partitions the utterance in the focal part and the presupposition. Thus he assumes that just as the specifier of the Focus head identifies the focus, the complement of the Focus head is the presupposition. Since the non-focal part of the utterance is the presupposition, a second (or third, etc.) focus would be part of the presupposition, and thus by definition would not be focal (Rizzi 1997: 14). 14

But the claim that the complement of the Focus head would be the presupposition is probably too strong. In fact, under such a view topics that precede a left-peripheral focus would not be part of the presupposition. So one has to weaken the statement that the LF representation of the presupposition is a continuous constituent (e.g., the complement of FP). But this opens up the possibility of a situation where two (or more) foci are identified in a clause and the rest of the utterance would be the presupposition. Such cases are attested. For instance, the Hungarian example in (74) has two foci:

(74)
Csak két lány
választott csak egy könyvet. Hungarian
only two girls chose only one book-acc
‘It was only two girls who chose only one book.’ (Kiss 1998: 16)

subsection.heading: 3.4.3 Left-peripheral vs. right-peripheral focus in Italian
subsection.p: Rizzi claims that the left-peripheral focus can be distinguished from a lower, right-peripheral focus position described in detail by Calabrese (1982), Cinque (1993), Belletti and Shlonsky (1995), and Samek-Lodovici (1996).

One of the characteristics of the left-peripheral focus is that it is not appropriate as an answer to a question indicating non-contrastive new information. Rather, it is allowed as a correction, as in (75) (Rizzi 1997: 5): 15

(75)
a. A: Che cosa hai letto?
What thing have-you read
‘What did you read?’
B: #Il tuo libro
ho letto.
the his book have-I read
‘I read your book.’
b. A: Gianni ma dice che hai letto il suo libro.
John to-me said that have-you read the his book
‘John told me that you read his book.’
B: Il tuo libro
ho letto (, non il suo)
the his book have-I read not the his
‘I read your book, not his.’

Although Rizzi (1997: 6) claims that the right-peripheral focus is in situ, Samek-Lodovici (1996) showed that it can be targeted by movement. For instance, the example in (76) illustrates this. The canonical order of two internal arguments in Italian is direct object preceding dative PP (see 76a). This order can be altered, as in the answer in (76b), in such a way that main stress falls on the direct object, which is therefore focused:

(76)
Piero ha presentato Giorgio a Maria.
Piero has introduced Giorgio to Maria.
a. Chi non hai presentato a nessuno?
who not have-you introduced to no one
b. Non ho presentato a nessuno Gianni.
not have-I introduced to no one Gianni
‘I have introduced Gianni to no one.’ (Samek-Lodovici 1996)

To the extent that Samek-Lodovici's arguments turn out to be right, they raise a theoretical issue. The point is that according to Rizzi's Focus criterion, the focused element moves to an A-bar position in order to be licensed in this position at LF. Languages are parameterized with respect to the locus of this movement. On the one hand, Hungarian and Italian left-peripheral constructions are overt instances of such a movement operation. On the other, English focus movement is covert; its presence is only indirectly observable, for instance, as it induces weak crossover violation (Chomsky 1976). In the realm of the Focus criterion, there is no room for a construction that involves overt movement to a designated syntactic position other than the position where focus is licensed at LF. In the case of the Italian right-peripheral focus, this position is targeted overtly, while presumably, a further covert movement step places the focal element in the left-peripheral licensing position (Rizzi 1997: 6). What would be the reason for the (intermediate) overt movement step? The only possible way out seems to be to assume that there is more than one possible licensing position for foci: a right-peripheral one and a left-peripheral one. Thus movement into either of these would satisfy the Focus criterion. But the result of this proliferation of functional landing sites is an increased potential for overgeneration and for loss of predictive power.

A similar point is put forward in Horvath (1995). She argues that languages, such as Aghem, that have a low postverbal focus position pose a problem for the Focus criterion. Her argument is based on the fact that in this language the same low position hosts wh-elements as well. Given the assumption that a wh-element needs to take scope over the clause at LF for the wh-question interpretation to be felicitous, one needs to assume that there is a further covert movement step taking the wh-element from the low postverbal position to some high position from which the wh-element would take scope over the clause. However, this means that the reason for the focus movement – targeting the low postverbal position – could not have been to satisfy an LF requirement, as proposed by the Focus criterion, since the LF requirement on the wh-element is not satisfied without a further movement step. Thus the same question arises as before: what is the trigger for the (overt) movement operation to the postverbal focus position? Horvath's answer is that the trigger for focus movement is an S-structure requirement that the focus be adjacent to the V. This is clearly orthogonal to the LF requirement that wh-elements need to take scope at LF, so the puzzle dissolves. Note that Horvath's solution has an important insight in the sense that she claims that it is an S-structure rather than an LF requirement of the focus that triggers overt movement to some designated position. Nevertheless, the proposed adjacency requirement cannot be the whole explanation, as, for instance, in Italian neither the left-peripheral nor the right-peripheral focus position is obligatorily adjacent to the V.

subsection.heading: 3.5 Focus movement is like wh-movement: discussion
3.5.1 Adjacency requirement
subsection.p: One characteristic property that suggests a similar treatment of focus and wh is that in many languages both of these elements require adjacency to the verb. This has been shown for Hungarian in section 1.3.3, for Basque in section 3.3, and for a postverbal focus language Podoko in section 2.3.

The adjacency requirement is often explained by the fact that the focus or wh-element is in the specifier of a functional head, while the verb occupies the head position. Therefore, focus (or wh) and verb are necessarily adjacent, since there is no intervening syntactic position between a leftward specifier and a head in the head–complement order.
It is important to note that, as Rizzi (1997: 16) shows, in Italian the parallel breaks down, since the adjacency requirement is present for wh but not for preverbal focus:

(77)
Questo
Gianni ti dira’ (non quello che pensavi).
this John you-dat say-fut.3 not which that thought.2
‘This Gianni will say to you, not what you thought.’
*Che cosa Gianni ti dira’?
what John you-dat say-fut.3
‘What will Gianni say to you?’ (Rizzi 1997: ex. 48)
Accordingly, Rizzi (1997) hypothesizes that the Focus head attracts the verb in wh-constructions, but not in focus constructions.

subsection.heading: 3.5.2 Pied-piping
subsection.p: Another similarity between focus movement and wh-movement is that they both exhibit pied-piping. As the following data illustrate, Hungarian focus movement (cf. 78a) is similar to Hungarian and English wh-movement (cf. 78b, c) in that sometimes the moved constituent is bigger than the actual focused or wh-element:

(78)
a. [FP [DP
Használt
autót] vettem.]
second-hand car bought-I
b. [FP [DP
Melyik autót] vetted meg?]
which car-acc bought-you VM
c. [CP [DP Whose car] did you buy?]

On the basis that focus and wh both exhibit pied-piping, Kenesei (1998: 40) argues that wh and focus should be treated alike, in terms of a syntactic [+wh]- and [+F]-feature, and that pied-piping should be accounted for in terms of feature percolation.

Horvath (2000: 197) showed that the parallelism between pied-piping in focus and wh does not go all the way in Hungarian. In particular, the wh-feature cannot be pied-piped from an object onto the participial clause (79a–b). Nevertheless, focus interpretation of the structurally parallel object in (79c) is allowed. This, she suggests, indicates that a different treatment for focus and wh is necessary in the grammar:

(79)
a. *az ital amit követelő vendégektől fél a pincér

‘the drink customers demanding which the waiter is afraid of . . .’

‘Customers demanding what is the waiter afraid of?’

‘It is customers demanding apricot brandy that the waiter is afraid of.’

However, according to Ortiz de Urbina (1999: 317), there is absolute parallelism between the pied-piping properties of focus and wh in Basque, suggesting that the Hungarian restriction on wh-pied-piping may just be a language-particular property.

Several languages are reported in the literature as exhibiting so-called clausal pied-piping (cf. Hermon 1984 on Quechua; Ortiz de Urbina 1990 on Basque; and Simpson and Bhattacharya 2000 on Bangla). In these cases, a wh-word or focus undergoes movement to a designated position inside the embedded clause, while the whole embedded clause gets pied-piped to the matrix wh or focus position. This is illustrated for Bangla in (80a, b) and for Basque in (81a, b). (82a, b) illustrate that clausal pied-piping is ungrammatical in Hungarian:

subsection.heading: 3.5.3 Overt manifestations of the Focus head: Somali
subsection.p: The languages discussed so far, namely Italian, Hungarian, and Basque, give no overt morphological evidence for the presence of a Focus head. However, there are languages that have morphological focus markers that have been analyzed as functional heads. Somali is a case at hand.
As reported in Hyman and Watters (1984), in Somali, the marker -baa/-buu is attached to a focused XP, while the prefix waa- attaches to focused verbs:

(84)
a. Cali-baa moos cunay.
Ali-FM banana ate
‘Ali ate a banana.’
b. Cali MOOS-buu cunay.
‘Ali ate a banana.’
c. Cali moos waa-cunay.
‘Ali ate a banana.’

Svolaccia et al. (1995) and Lecarme (1999) question all of Hyman and Watters's (1984) claim. Rather they argue that the focus particles sit in Infl or C, and the [Spec, CP] position is available for focused constituents, while topics adjoin to CP. 16

The argument that -baa is dependent on the V rather than on the preceding NP comes from gapping. Gapping the V in a coordinate structure renders the presence of a focus marker ungrammatical, suggesting that -baa is dependent on the V rather than on the NP:

(85)
a. Ma Maxamed baa tegay mise Cabdi baa tegay?
Q Maxamed FM went or Cabdi FM went
‘Has Maxamed gone or has Cabdi gone?’
b. Ma Maxamed
baa tegay mise Cabdi?
Q Maxamed FM went or Cabdi
‘Has Maxamed gone or has Cabdi?’
c. *Ma Maxamed
baa tegay mise Cabdi
baa?
Q Maxamed FM went or Cabdi FM
‘Has Maxamed gone or has Cabdi?’
(Saeed 1984: 110)

Both Svolaccia et al. (1995) and Lecarme (1999) suggest that a focused constituent appears preverbally as a result of movement to the specifier of a functional head that hosts the focus particle. So the examples above are analyzed as in (86):

(86)
a. [CP
Cali-[C baa] moos cunay]
Ali-FM banana ate
‘Ali ate a banana.’
b. [CP Cali[CP moos-[C buu] cunay]]
‘Ali ate a banana.’

If this is on the right track, then Somali is essentially analyzed like Hungarian by Brody (1995a) or Italian by Rizzi (1997). The focus moves to the specifier of a matching functional head. Moreover, the focus feature in Somali is overtly manifest in the form of a morphological marker.

Note, however, that the following data are interesting in this respect. Somali, just like Italian or Hungarian, allows for wide focal sentences. The question–answer pairs appear to look as follows (Svolaccia et al. 1995: 73–75). It seems that both O and VP focus are possible if the O is focus marked and fronted (87a–c). The subject, which is mentioned in the question, has to be a topic or a postverbal constituent in the answer (87c). It is inappropriate to focus mark the V even in VP-focus (87d):

(87)
QVP: Cali muxuu sameeyay?
Cali what-FM-he did
‘What did Cali do?’
QO: Cali yuu dilay?
Cali whom-FM-he beat
‘Who did Cali beat?’
a. Cali Maryan buu dilay.
Cali Maryan FM-he beat
b. Maryan buu dilay Cali.
Maryan FM-he beat Cali
c. *Cali baa Maryan dilay.
Cali FM Maryan beat
d. *Cali Maryan wuu dilay.
Cali Maryan FM-he beat
‘Cali beat Maryan’ or ‘Cali beat Maryan.’

If the context question suggests IP-focus, the most appropriate answer is to put the marker -baa on the subject (88a). To focus mark the object is more marked (88b). It is inappropriate to put either the subject or the object either in prefocal or postverbal position (88c). These positions most probably indicate discourse-linked status, which is incompatible with the context question, which requires an all-focus utterance as the answer:

(88)
QIP: Maxaad hacay?
What-FM happened
‘What happened?’
a. Cali baa Maryan dilay.
Cali FM Maryan beat
b. (?)Maryan baa Cali dilay.
Maryan FM Cali beat
c. *Cali Maryan buu dilay.
Cali Maryan FM-he beat
d. *Maryan buu dilay Cali.
Maryan FM-he beat Cali
e. *Maryan Cali baa dilay.
Maryan Cali FM beat
f. *Cali baa dilay Maryan.
Cali FM beat Maryan
‘Cali beat Maryan.’

The point of these examples with respect to the functional head status of -baa is that the moved element that sits in the specifier of the head bearing focus morphology is not necessarily the focus of the utterance, albeit it is always part of the focus. This seriously undermines the idea that the trigger for the movement operation would be focus and that the head in question would be Focus head. If it were, then the moved constituent sitting in its specifier would have to receive a focal interpretation obligatorily.

subsection.heading: 3.5.4 Focus and weak crossover revisited
subsection.p: Recall from section 3.1 that one of the two basic pillars of the analyses that take focus constructions to be a case of syntactic movement, similar to wh-movement, is that focus displays weak crossover effects (Chomsky 1976).
The argument goes as follows. Backward coreference is ruled out if the full DP is focused, while allowed if not. Thus (53b), as opposed to (53a) (repeated here as (89a–b)) is ungrammatical:

(89)
a. The man that shei met LIKED Maryi.
b. *The man that shei met liked MARY i.
LF: Maryi [the man that shei met liked ti]
(90) *Whoi does the man that shei met like ti?

As the LF representation of (89b) indicates, Chomsky (1976) argued the focus is preposed at LF. Thus (89b) is similar to (54a) (repeated here as (90)), where the movement of the wh-element across a co-indexed pronoun is ruled out as a weak crossover violation. In a parallel fashion, in (89b), the fronting of the focal element at LF presents a weak crossover violation.

We have already noted that this argument is considerably weakened by the observation of Jackendoff (1972) that focus disregards syntactic islands. This is illustrated in (54b) (repeated here as (91)) for a complex NP island. If focusing involved LF movement, that would mean that focus movement (or maybe LF movement in general) is different from overt movement in that it does not observe islands – an undesirable outcome:
(91) Sam only saw a [NP man [CP who was wearing a RED hat]]

But there are additional arguments against a weak crossover analysis of the lack of backward anaphora with a focused constituent. Williams (1997) points out that a weak crossover account is too restrictive, as it incorrectly predicts that ‘backward-and-down’ anaphora cases like (92) are ungrammatical. This is because (92) would yield the LF indicated, which contains a weak crossover violation:

(92)
Anyone who has written iti can turn his TERM PAPERi in to me.
LF: his TERM PAPERi [anyone who has written iti can turn ti in to me].
(Williams 1997: ex. 33a; diacritics added)

Furthermore, an alternative analysis of the relevant data is possible. It is possible to show that (89b) is ungrammatical for a reason that has nothing to do with the status of the bound pronominal. Rather, what renders the utterance ungrammatical is that Mary is an ill-formed focus.

Rochemont (1986) argued for the generalization of c-construability, according to which any constituent is focus if and only if it is not c-construable from the earlier discourse. In other words, a constituent bears prosodic prominence if and only if it is not accessibly discourse-linked (Neeleman and Reinhart 1998). For this reason, utterances such as (93) are ungrammatical, as they contain a focus marked element, John, which has just been introduced to the discourse in the previous utterance in a salient way:
(93) John and Mary danced on the floor. *Then JOHN kissed Mary.

This could very well be the reason for the ungrammaticality of (89b) as well. Such examples pose a paradox for discourse. Either the pronoun is not licensed in the absence of an antecedent, or focus on Mary is ill-formed. Let us see why this is the case. In (89b) Mary bears prosodic prominence, indicating focus. By c-construability this means that it cannot be linked to an entity mentioned in previous discourse. At the same time, the utterance contains a pronoun he. Unless they are interpreted deictically, pronouns need an accessible entity in the discourse. If the previous discourse contains an accessible entity as the antecedent of the pronoun, which allows the use of the pronoun in (89b), then this same accessible discourse entity renders focus on Mary ill-formed, as it causes a c-construability violation.

If the preceding discourse does not contain an earlier mention of Mary, and thus focus on it is allowed by c-construability, then there is no discourse antecedent for the pronoun to rely on. There cannot be one by c-construability. (If there were an antecedent, Mary could not be focused, and we just assumed it can be.) Note, however, that it is not completely impossible to use a pronoun when an antecedent is not present in earlier discourse: for instance, in cases when the antecedent is in the same utterance as the pronoun. This is known as backward anaphora. It is even possible for such utterances to be discourse-initial. Some examples are given here from Carden (1982), reported in Reinhart (1981):

(94)
a. Because they wanted to know more about the ocean's current, students in the science club at Mark Twain Junior High School of Coney Island gave ten bottles with return address card inside to crewmen of the NY city's sludge barges. (New York Times)
b. When she was five years old, a child of my acquaintance announced a theory that she was acquainted with rabbits. (New York Times)

In principle, this means that (89) could be a case of backward anaphora, where there is no antecedent available for the pronoun in the previous discourse; rather its antecedent is Mary in the same utterance. However, this possibility is ruled out by Reinhart's (1981: fn. 9) generalization, originally proposed by Kuno (1972a), which says that backward anaphora is restricted to cases where the antecedent is the topic. This is indeed the case in the examples in (94). 17 In contrast, the antecedent is the focus in (89b). Since an element cannot be topic and focus at the same time, (89b) can be ruled out as a discourse violation without any mention of weak crossover.

As a final point, it can be shown that (89b) can be rendered grammatical in certain discourse contexts, indicating that it is not a syntactic (or semantic) but rather a discourse violation. According to c-construability, an entity cannot bear prosodic prominence if it is not a new entity in the discourse. However, there are exceptions to this generalization. Contrastively focused constituents may bear focal prominence even if they are not new:

(95)
A: Sally and the woman John loves is leaving the country today.
B: I thought that the woman he loves has BETRAYED Sally.
A: No, the woman hei loves betrayed JOHNi. (Rochemont 1986)

In (95), John is contrastively focused. In fact, the second utterance of A is a correction of B's utterance. So John, even though it is not new to the discourse, still does not violate c-construability, as it is contrasted with Sally in B's utterance. As we see, coreference between John and he is allowed. If one pursued an analysis that renders (89b) ungrammatical as a weak crossover violation, one would have to assume that focus fronting does not affect constituents that are contrastively focused, only ones that are new to the discourse. This way, it would be possible to exclude cases like (89) while still permitting cases like (95). However, this assumption would be counter-intuitive in light of the semantics associated with Hungarian focus movement discussed in section 1.3.4. There it was shown that Hungarian focus movement is necessarily contrastive; however, it need not affect foci that are new to the discourse. So under this proposal Hungarian would come out just the opposite of English.

subsection.heading: 4.1 Accent to focus vs. focus to accent
subsection.p: It is a well known characteristic of focus, which has been alluded to previously but not stated explicitly, that at least in English, the focus of the utterance is always marked by some kind of prosodic prominence: main stress or pitch accent. This generalization is the Stress–Focus Correspondence Principle (see 96). This has been known since Chomsky (1971), Jackendoff (1972), and Selkirk (1984, 1986) (in the functionalist literature, Dezső 1974, Harlig and Bardovi-Harlig 1988):

li.p: The focus of an utterance always contains the main stress of the utterance.

subsection.p: Ladd (1996) divides approaches to focus into two groups on the basis of the perspective they take with respect to stress–focus correspondence. All of the analyses discussed so far exemplify what he calls the ‘accent-to-focus’ view. In these approaches, focus is determined by the presence of a syntactic (or semantic) focus feature, rather than by the position of stress. The prosodic characteristic of focus is secondary: main stress is assigned to the constituent marked as focus in syntax. This view has its origins in Jackendoff's (1972) proposal, which argued for the presence of syntactic focus marking.

However, we have seen in section 3.5.4 that the reasoning behind the idea that focus movement is like other instances of movement in syntax, such as wh-movement, is questionable in languages like English. Rather, certain properties of focus can be explained by discourse principles, not syntactic ones. This opens up the way to question the idea that focus would be a syntactic construct in the first place. In other words, if the arguments that focus movement would be similar to wh-movement are weakened, one might wonder why focus movement would be a case of feature-driven movement, even in languages where it happens overtly. In fact, one can go one step further and ask why a syntactic [+Focus]-feature would exist in the first place. The analyses reviewed in section 4.3 take these questions as their starting point. They belong to what Ladd (1996) called the ‘focus-to-accent’ view. In these proposals, it is assumed that there is an independent prosodic operation, the nuclear stress rule, that assigns main stress to the utterance. The focus is determined on the basis of the prosodic properties of the utterance: a constituent bearing main stress is a possible focus of the utterance. This view goes back to Chomsky's (1971) work and was later revived by Cinque (1993) and others.

Some of these proposals are described in section 4.3. But before we come to them, we first have to evaluate the reasons for which the previous analyses all assumed the existence of a syntactic [+Focus]-feature. It will become clear from the discussion in section 4.2 that the two perspectives with respect to (96) are fundamentally different in their conception of the architecture of the grammar. The T-model, where phonological information is stripped off before the derivation reaches the conceptual interface, can only be maintained in the accent-to-focus view. This is what prompted all the analyses described above to assume the existence of some form of syntactic focus marking. However, the focus-to-accent view requires the availability of prosodic information at the interface. If focus, a semantic (or pragmatic) notion, is determined by the position of main stress, then it is evident that such prosodic information has to be available at the level of representation where focus is relevant, so the derivation cannot branch into a PF and an LF branch. In contrast, as argued in section 4.4, the accent-to-focus view has a conceptual advantage of its own. It maintains Chomsky's (1995c) Inclusiveness Principle, which is violated by all focus-to-accent views assuming the existence of a syntactic [+Focus]-feature.

subsection.heading: 4.2 The accent-to-focus view and the T-model
subsection.p: In the GB/Minimalist framework, phonological information, which is ultimately relevant for the interface of the grammar in its wide sense with sensori-motor apparatus (i.e., the articulatory and auditory devices), is separated from syntactic (or syntactico-semantic) information, which ultimately feeds the interface of the grammar with the conceptual-intentional system. This is known as the T-model (see (97)):

One of the motivations behind the T-model is that phonology is a module whose role is merely to interpret the output of the (overt) syntactic component for the sensori-motor apparatus. 18 Consider the Stress–Focus Correspondence Principle in (96). It is clear that it cannot be stated in the T-model at any level of representation (i.e., either at PF or at LF), as it refers to prosodic information and the LF notion focus at the same time. 19

Let us see whether the feature-driven account can be extended to account for (96) without violating the assumptions of the T-model. Although the standard account remained agnostic on the issue of focus– stress correspondence, it can be easily extended to account for the fact that in both English and Hungarian the focused constituent receives main stress. Let us use a tree-based metrical system to indicate stress placement (following Liberman and Prince 1977; Liberman 1979). In this notation, Strong and Weak (S/W) labels are assigned to the binary branching structure, and main stress is on the node that bears S and that is only dominated by nodes bearing S. In this system, main stress falls on the element that bears an S label and that is only dominated by nodes that bear S labels. To derive the fact that main stress falls on the focused element, all we have to assume is the following (Jackendoff 1972: 241; cf. also Selkirk 1996 and Kenesei 1998):

li.p: Assign S to the node marked [+F] and to any dominating node.

subsection.p: As (99) and (100) illustrate, the feature-based analysis gives the right word order and the right stress pattern in both English and Hungarian. In particular, the [+F]-marked element, Mari ‘Mary’, in (99) is marked S together with the only dominating node, the root node. This ensures that Mari ‘Mary’ receives main stress in (99). Similarly, the focused element bearing [+F] in (100), the map, is assigned an S label by (98), together with all the dominating nodes, such as the W, VP, F, IP, F, and FP nodes. As a result the focused element the map will receive main stress: 20

Thus, one may conclude that the feature-driven approach to focus is able to account for the basic syntactic and prosodic facts, while maintaining the hypothesis of no direct PF–LF communication implicit in the T-model. Nevertheless, this approach violates Chomsky's (1995c) Inclusiveness Principle, in the sense that the lexical item where [+F] is introduced into the derivation does not have any specific lexical property corresponding to the feature [+F]. The terminal node is not itself focused; rather it is part of the focus. So [+F] cannot be taken to be an interpretable feature on the terminal node where it is introduced into the derivation. (See section 4.4.3 for more discussion of this issue.)

subsection.heading: 4.3 The focus-to-accent view
subsection.p: Ever since Jackendoff (1972), the accent-to-focus view was predominant in the literature until recently. This was due to a variety of factors, one of which is the conceptual issue spelt out above. But there were empirical arguments in favor of this view as well. First, as we have seen in the discussion in section 3, the assumption of a syntactic focus feature is a straightforward way to provide a uniform analysis for languages with focus movement and those without it. But recall that the idea so fundamental to this position, namely the discussion of the alleged weak crossover violations, was challenged in section 3.5.4, where it was shown that an alternative explanation of these facts exists that analyzes these cases as discourse violations. Nevertheless, the presence of syntactic focus movement has to be accommodated in any analysis of focus. The assumption of a syntactic focus feature is useful in this regard, given Chomsky's (1995c) proposal that movement is feature-driven. This issue will be addressed in section 4.3.2. In addition, as Reinhart (1995, forthcoming) notes, the focus-to-accent view crucially relies on the distinction between neutral stress and focal stress, which was challenged both empirically and conceptually during the 1980 (see Reinhart forthcoming for a review). However, Cinque (1993) reopened the issue and argued forcefully that the distinction exists and thus a focus-to-accent view might be tenable. To illustrate how such a proposal would work, let us see Reinhart's (1995, forthcoming) proposal in more detail.

subsection.heading: 4.3.1 Reinhart's (1995, forthcoming) focus-to-accent view
subsection.p: Reinhart (1995, forthcoming) and Neeleman and Reinhart (1998) assume that it is the prosodic make-up of the utterance, rather than its syntactic characteristics, that encodes focus in the grammar. In particular, in Reinhart's theory, focus is not encoded by a syntactic feature; rather the prosody of the utterance determines the possible foci in accordance with the stress-focus correspondence generalization, following Chomsky (1971). The Stress–Focus Correspondence Principle (96) is repeated here for convenience: 21

li.p: The focus of an utterance always contains the main stress of the utterance.

subsection.p: In particular, Reinhart (1995, forthcoming) argues that the focus of an utterance is determined by its intonation. A particular utterance may have more than one focus interpretation. They define the set of possible foci for a given utterance as follows:
(102) The focus set of IP consists of the constituents containing the main stress of IP. (Reinhart 1995, forthcoming)

Thus the utterance in (103), where main stress falls on the object, has the focus set given in (104). Accordingly, it is felicitous in the context of the questions in (103), indicating IP, VP, and DP-DO focus, respectively:

(103)
a. A: What's this noise?
B: My neighbour is building a DESK.
b. A: What's your neighbour doing?
B: My neighbour is building a DESK.
c. A: What's your neighbour building?
B: My neighbour is building a DESK.
(Neeleman and Reinhart 1998: 333, ex. 53)
(104) Focus set: {IP, VP, DPDO}

In Reinhart's (1995, forthcoming) approach, the output of the grammar is an ambiguous utterance with more than one possible focus interpretation. Depending on the discourse conditions, one interpretation is chosen as the actual focus. However, discourse may only select a member of the focus set, and may not select a constituent outside the focus set. Thus the answer in (103a) is inappropriate in the context of the question in (105), as that context requires DP-SU focus, which is not in the focus set of the utterance. It is equally inappropriate in the context of (106), as that requires focus on the V, which is also not in the focus set of the utterance:

li.p: B: #My neighbour is building a DESK.
A: Has your neighbour bought a desk already?
B: #No, my neighbour is building a DESK.

subsection.p: Reinhart (1995, forthcoming) follows Cinque (1993) in arguing that every language has a neutral, unmarked stress pattern, assigned by the nuclear stress rule (NSR). In English, the result of the NSR is main stress on the rightmost constituent, i.e., on the object in a transitive construction. If the focus set defined by the NSR does not contain the intended focus of the utterance, a special operation may apply to place stress on the constituent in question:
(107) Relocate main stress. (Neeleman and Reinhart 1998: 333, ex. 55)

By (107), in the context of (108a), a marked stress (not the one assigned by NSR) is assigned to the DP-SU, and in (108b) to the V. As a result, the focus set of the utterance, defined by the main stress, contains the relevant constituents, and the utterances are appropriate in their given contexts. In fact, in their contexts, the utterances do not seem marked; they are perfectly natural:

(108)
a. A: Who's building a desk?
B: My NEIGHBOUR is building a desk.
b. A: Has your neighbour bought a desk already?
B: No, my neighbour is BUILDING a desk.
(Neeleman and Reinhart 1998: 334, ex. 56)

Reinhart (1995, forthcoming) argues that there is a very precise sense in which the utterances in (108) can be viewed as marked. They both involve an optional operation: stress shift. Stress shift is an optional operation in the sense that performing it is not necessary to save the derivation from crashing at the interfaces. Stress shift does not apply to turn an otherwise ill-formed expression into a well-formed one, as, for instance, movement of the object to [Spec, TP] in English passives does. Rather, the utterance would be well-formed even if stress shift did not apply. Nevertheless, such optional operations are not totally unrestricted. Reinhart argues that they apply if and only if they have an effect on the interpretation. In other words, such operations can be viewed as marked in the sense that they lead to ungrammaticality unless they derive an interpretation that was otherwise unavailable. This intuition is formalized in the following definition:

p.b: Reference set computation at the interface:

li.p: Take fully derived (syntactically and prosodically) structures Di and their interpretations Ii as ordered pairs. <D1, I1> is ruled out at the interface if and only if there exists <D2, I1>, and D2 involves fewer operations (syntactic or prosodic) than D1.

subsection.p: To illustrate how interface economy operates, compare the exchange in (108a) with the infelicitous exchange in (110):

li.p: B: #My NEIGHBOR is building a desk.

subsection.p: The same utterance is appropriate as an answer to a question that requires subject focus (cf. 108a), but it is inappropriate as an answer to an all-focus (i.e., IP-focus) question (cf. 110). The stress-shifting operation that places stress on the subject is legitimate under a reading that puts focus on the subject, as subject focus was not available unless stress strengthening applied to the subject. The same operation is, however, illegitimate under a reading such as the all-focus reading, because there exists an expression – the neutrally stressed utterance (103a) – where the optional operation did not apply and where the same all-focus reading is available. In this way, Reinhart (1995, forthcoming) accounts for the well-known generalization that wide focus readings (i.e., focus on a constituent larger than the stress-bearing element) are blocked from certain positions (see Selkirk 1984, 1986, and many others).

To summarize, Reinhart (1995, forthcoming) argues that the set of possible foci of an utterance is determined by the main stress of the utterance. If focus is required on an element that is not in the focus set of the unmarked utterance, where stress is assigned by the NSR, then an optional stress-strengthening operation may assign stress to the element, to make it available in the focus set of the marked utterance. Reinhart is an advocate of the focus-to-accent view. She argues that it is the set of possible foci, rather than the actual focus of the utterance, that is determined by the grammatical representation of the sentence, where grammatical representation is understood in the wider sense of including the prosodic representation as well as syntactic structure.

subsection.heading: 4.3.2 Focus movement in the focus-to-accent view
subsection.p: Cinque's (1993) and Reinhart's (1995, forthcoming) revival of the focus-to-accent view has become influential for analyses of focus movement. The idea that the focus of an utterance is determined by the prosodic make-up of the utterance led to the formulation of analyses that take focus movement to be essentially prosodically driven. 22

subsection.heading: 4.3.2.1 Zubizarreta (1998): p-movement
subsection.p: Zubizarreta's (1998) analysis of certain movement operations in Spanish, which she termed p-movement, was one of the first in the literature to be proposed along these lines. She observed that alongside the VSO and SVO orders, VOS order is also grammatical in Spanish. In this order the subject is not right-dislocated. An example is given in (111):

(111)
a. Quién te regaló la bottella de vino?
who you-dat gave the bottle of wine
‘Who gave you the bottle of wine?’
b. Me regaló la botella de vino MARIA.
me-dat gave the bottle of wine Maria
‘Maria gave me the bottle of wine.’

As the question in (111a) indicates, the VOS order in Spanish is felicitous as an answer to a question asking for the identity of the subject. Given that (111b) need not be interpreted contrastively, but rather is felicitous in a question–answer pair, Zubizarreta hypothesizes that the stress on the subject is neutral; in other words, it is the NSR rather than her proposed additional focal stress rule that assigns stress to the subject in VOS structures.

As it is a characteristic property of nuclear stress that it allows for focus projection, it is expected that wide focal interpretations are available in VOS structures, just as in VSO and SVO orders. This is not the case. Zubizarreta (1998: 127) offers the following explanation. The VOS order is not a basic order; rather it is derived from VSO (or SVO) order by preposing the object. The movement operation is a last-resort operation, triggered only if the subject needs to be focused. It is not feature-driven movement, but rather prosodically motivated movement. Hence the term p-movement.

An important argument in favor of this conclusion comes from the fact that the VOS order is only allowed in contexts that indicate that the subject is focused. No other constituent can be contrastively focused in the VOS order by the focal stress rule. (This possibility is not excluded in SVO and VSO orders.) This is illustrated in (112):

(112)
*Me regaló la botella de VINO
María.
me-dat gave the bottle of wine Maria
‘Maria gave me the bottle of wine.’

This can be understood if the fronting of the object was motivated by allowing the subject to be positioned where nuclear stress falls. If the focal stress rule applied and placed focal stress on another constituent, the fronting of the object would have been a superfluous operation, thus ruled out by last resort.

Zubizarreta shows that p-movement is a strictly local process, and she concludes that the empirical arguments that are available are insufficient to determine whether it applies prior to Spell Out or after Spell Out. She assumes that it applies in the final stretch of the overt syntactic derivation just before the derivation branches to PF and LF. (Her analysis maintains the T-model, although with significant modifications, including the introduction of a separate level of representation at the point of branching. See Zubizarreta 1998 for discussion.)

subsection.heading: 4.3.2.2 Stress-driven focus movement
subsection.p: A similar analysis of Hungarian focus movement is put forward in Szendrői (2001, 2003). This analysis takes Reinhart's (1995) proposal as its starting point. It also relies on the fact that main stress in Hungarian is assigned to the leftmost constituent of the clause, rather than the rightmost constituent as it is in English or Italian.

Szendrői argues that Brody's (1990b, 1995a) analysis of Hungarian focus is correct as far as the syntactic configuration is concerned: the focus moves to a specifier of a functional head and the verb adjoins to the head leaving its particle behind (see section 3.4.1). However, the motivation for the movement is not that the functional head in question has a [+Focus]-feature. Rather, the focused element moves in order to be in the position where main stress is assigned. As a result, it can be interpreted as the focus by the Reinhartian assumption that focus is identified as the constituent that contains main stress. Thus Hungarian focus movement is not feature-driven; rather it targets the position where main stress is assigned.

There are at least two important characteristics of Hungarian focus movement that follow from this hypothesis. First, focus movement in Hungarian is unique. In other words, utterances with multiple foci involve only a single instance of focus movement. The other foci remain in situ. This is illustrated in (113):

(113)
Q: Mit adtál oda kinek?
what-acc gave-you prt who-dat
‘What did you give to whom?’
A: A könyvet
adtam oda Marinak, és a tollat
adtam oda Péternek.
the book-acc gave-I prt Mary-dat and the pen-acc gave-I prt Peter-dat
A′: *A könyvet adtam Marinak oda, és a tollat adtam Péternek oda.
‘I gave the book to Mary and the pen to Peter.’

This follows from the fact that the NSR assigns a single main stress, so there is a single position in every clause where main stress falls. If focus movement targets this position, only one focused constituent can be moved. The remaining foci acquire stress by a prosodic operation that assigns extra stresses.

Another characteristic of Hungarian focus that is explained by the proposal that Hungarian focus movement is driven by the need for the focus constituent to get stressed is that verb focusing in Hungarian does not involve the separation of the verbal particle from the verb. Given that verb movement strands the particle, the fact that the prt-V order is undisturbed in cases of verb focus suggests that the verbal complex is in situ. So verb focusing appears not to involve movement:

(114)
a. Elvitted a gyereket az állatkertbe?
prt-took-you the child-acc the zoo-loc
‘Did you take the child to the zoo?’
b.
Elvittem a gyereket az állatkertbe.
*Vittem el a gyereket az állatkertbe.
‘I took the child to the zoo.’

This is explained in the stress-driven analysis of focus movement, as main stress falls on the verbal complex by the NSR even if it is in situ. Given that the verbal complex occupies a left-peripheral position within the VP, it receives stress by the NSR and thus may acquire focus interpretation in situ. As there is no reason for it to move, it stays in situ.

So Szendrői (2001, 2003) argues that focus movement in Hungarian is prosodically motivated. It targets a left-peripheral position because the main stress rule in Hungarian is leftward oriented. In contrast, main stress in Italian is rightward oriented, as it is in English. But unlike in English, the prosodic operation of stress shift is not available in Italian. Rather, Italian displays focus movement, just as Hungarian does. However, in contrast to Hungarian focus movement, Italian focus movement targets a right-peripheral position, in accordance with the directionality of the stress rule in the language. This is the right-peripheral focus position that was mentioned in section 3.4.3. (See Lambrecht 1994; Szendrői 2001, 2002; for further discussion on this point.)

subsection.heading: 4.3.2.3 Hungarian focus movement revisited (Horvath 2000)
subsection.p: Szendrői's (2001, 2003) work is not the only account in the literature concerning Hungarian focus movement and prosody. Horvath (2000) provides a reanalysis of her earlier work on Hungarian focus movement in light of Reinhart's (1995) proposal that stress determines the focus of an utterance. Horvath notes that in accordance with Reinhart's hypothesis, the fronted focused constituent in Hungarian bears main stress. She accepts Reinhart's view that it is this prosodic property that determines the focal interpretation of the constituent, rather than its position. She proposes that the movement of focused constituents in Hungarian is thus not actually driven by the fact that they are interpreted as foci. Rather, it is another distinctive characteristic of Hungarian focus that motivates the movement to the preverbal position: exhaustive identification.

Recall from section 1.3.4 that a characteristic semantic property of Hungarian focus movement is that it provides an exhaustive listing. Thus preverbal focus in Hungarian “exhaustively identifies the proper subset of a contextually relevant set of entities as the one for which the predicate holds” (Horvath 2000: 201). This is illustrated by the contrast in (115). Horvath shows that (115c), which indicates an answer whose focus is not exhaustive, cannot involve focus movement to the preverbal position:

(115)
Q: Kit hívtak meg?
a. A: Jánost
hívták meg.
John-acc invited prt
‘They invited John (and no one else).’
b. A′:Meghívták *(például/többek között) Jánost.
invited-they for-example/others among John-acc
‘They invited John, for example/among others’
c. A″:*Jánost
például hívták meg.
John-acc for-example invited prt
‘They invited John, for example/among others’

Horvath (2000) concludes that the preverbal position in Hungarian is a grammaticalized position for exhaustive identification. Thus the movement to the preverbal position is in no sense a case of focus movement; rather it is a case of movement for exhaustive identification.

subsection.heading: 4.4.1 Ways of encoding focus in the grammar
subsection.p: The most basic characteristic difference between the feature-based approach to focus and the prosodically oriented approaches is that the former encode focus in the syntactic representation, while the latter do so in the prosodic representation.

Recall that in section 1.2.2 it was argued that GB and Minimalist approaches to focus are the strictest, in the sense that they advocate encoding focus in the grammar directly and unambiguously. Let us note that in this light, another characteristic difference between the feature-driven approach and the prosodically oriented is that the former determines the unique and unambiguous focus of the utterance, while the latter define the set of possible foci. The actual focus is selected from this set by the discourse context. Thus, in the focus-to-accent view, there is no one-to-one correspondence between an expression (comprising a syntactic representation and a prosodic representation) and its focus interpretation. Rather there is a one-to-many correspondence; each expression is associated with a set of potential foci.

A final general point with respect to the accent-to-focus view is that stating the Stress–Focus Correspondence Principle at the interface means that some kind of marking of focus that is legible from the prosodic representation should be universal. Being at the interface between the grammar and the conceptual system, it is highly unlikely that there would be a sufficient system of overt cues that would enable the acquisition of this principle. Thus, the stress-based theory makes a strong and easily falsifiable prediction: namely, there is no language where focus is marked only by a specific syntactic position without an accompanying prosodic marking (stress or tone) or a morpheme. In contrast, the absence of such languages would be unexpected under the accent-to-focus view.

subsection.heading: 4.4.2 Adjacency, edge-sensitivity, and directionality
subsection.p: Recall that feature-based approaches to focus movement fall in two classes: those that argue that focus is essentially parallel to case in the sense that there is an adjacency requirement between focus and verb (section 2); and those that argue that focus movement is similar to wh-movement (section 3). Let us now examine the stress-based approaches to focus movement in comparison to these approaches.

In a stress-driven approach to focus movement, the quantificational characteristics of focus movement are hard to capture. To the extent that focus movement is really movement for stress, it is unclear why it should be in complementary distribution with wh-movement, license parasitic gaps, or instantiate any other characteristics that are normally associated with operator-variable dependencies. Under the view that focus movement is in fact movement for exhaustive interpretation, the quantificational properties of the focus construction are easier to understand, as in this case some kind of operator is involved. 23

A potential advantage of the stress-based view is that it offers a new perspective on the syntax of focus movement in the following sense. Cross-linguistically, focus movement seems to instantiate characteristics that are typical prosodic properties, such as adjacency, edge-sensitivity, and directionality.

Adjacency requirements are attested elsewhere in the grammar. Many such areas are typically prosodic in nature. The most straightforward case is cliticization. Clitics, which tend to instantiate insufficient prosodic weight, have to appear either immediately to the left or immediately to the right of the verb (or the finite auxiliary or the complementizer) in many languages. 24

Edge-sensitivity is also often attested in prosody. For instance, extra-metricality is a typical edge phenomenon. For example, in syllables the nucleus is the most sonorous. Sonority increases from the start of the onset toward the nucleus, and decreases after the nucleus toward the end of coda cluster. In English, at the edges of the phonological word, an additional coronal [s] may be added to the beginning of an onset cluster even if it is followed by a less sonorous consonant, as in s[tri, or to the end of a coda cluster even if it is more sonorous than the final consonant of the coda cluster, as in ark]s.

Headedness is also edge-sensitive. For instance, in foot structure, iambs are right-headed, while trochees are left-headed. There are feet that have three moras, but these have either left-aligned heads or right-aligned ones; there is no foot structure involving three moras where the middle one is heavy and the ones on the edges are light. As Van der Hulst (1999) argued, stress systems in general are often edge-sensitive.

Finally, left and right directionality is also highly relevant in stress systems, as well as to cliticization (as in enclitics and proclitics). Although left and right asymmetries are often invoked in syntax as well, hierarchical notions such as c-command are the propotypical syntactic cases.

To sum up, the potential advantage of a prosodically oriented perspective on focus movement is that it easily accommmodates edge-sensitivity, adjacency, and left–right directionality, which are all widely attested to be relevant properties of focus constructions. The potential weakness of this approach is that it does not easily accommodate quantificational properties of focus constructions that are characteristic of operator-variable dependencies, unless something extra, such as an operator, is assumed.

subsection.heading: 4.4.3 The Inclusiveness Principle (Chomsky 1995c)
subsection.p: Another difference between the accent-to-focus view and the focus-to-accent view is that focus is encoded syntactically in the former, but not in the latter. As was shown at the beginning of this section, the latter view gives up the hypothesis of no direct PF–LF communication, or in other words the T-model. This appears to be a shortcoming, although see Jackendoff (1996, 2002b) for arguments to the contrary.

Whatever the nature of the architecture, the accent-to-focus view is not without conceptual difficulties of its own: this approach violates Chomsky's Inclusiveness Principle, which is maintained in the focus-to-accent view. Let us see the argumentation in detail.
As Zubizarreta (1998) observes, the notion of a [+Focus]-feature is conceptually problematic. In fact, Chomsky (1995c: 228) states that:

a ‘perfect language’ should meet the condition of inclusiveness: any structure formed by the computation . . . is constituted of elements already present in the lexical items selected for N [the numeration]; no new objects are added in the course of the computation apart from rearrangements of lexical properties . . . Let us assume that this condition holds (virtually) of the computation from N to LF (N → &lgr;).

In the original formulation of the feature-based approach adopted here (Jackendoff 1972), [+F] violates the Inclusiveness condition. In order to see this, recall the original proposal of Jackendoff (11), repeated here for convenience:

This proposal violates Inclusiveness in a very precise sense. According to Inclusiveness, in a Minimalist grammar there are two ways a node may acquire some property, i.e., a feature. A terminal node may be assigned a feature from the lexicon. A non-terminal node has to inherit its features from its daughters, which created the non-terminal node via merger. This is formulated as follows (cf. also Chomsky 1995c: 228):

li.p: The properties of a non-terminal node are fully recoverable from its daughters.
The properties of terminal nodes are recoverable from the mapping principles [between the lexical-conceptual system and the grammar].
(modified from Neeleman and Van de Koot 2002: 529)

subsection.p: In effect, Inclusiveness ensures that no information may enter the derivation via a non-terminal node, and thus that all the information present in the tree ultimately comes from a terminal node.

Given the first part of the definition of Inclusiveness (117a), it is not possible for a non-terminal node to possess a [+F]-feature if neither of its daughters has that feature. As a first step toward a solution, one may assign the [+F]-feature to terminal nodes, allow for its percolation to non-terminal nodes (cf. Selkirk 1984), and reformulate the LF-Interpretation Principle accordingly. The reformulated principles of [+F]-marking, percolation, and interpretation are given below:

li.p: Allow the percolation of [+F] from a node to a dominating node.
Interpret the largest [+F]-marked constituent as focus.

subsection.p: Note that this state of affairs violates Inclusiveness in the sense that it still contravenes (117b), the second clause of the definition – thus only in a weaker sense. (An approach based on (116) violates inclusiveness in a stronger sense, as it violates both clauses of (117).) The fact that [+F] satisfies the first clause, (117a), means that it behaves like other syntactic features in the grammar. This is important, as a syntactic encoding of a pragmatic notion would be rather unwelcome if it involved characteristics that are otherwise not normally present in syntax. Nevertheless, [+F] is clearly not a lexical feature. As is clearly stated by Jackendoff (1972), the notion of focus itself is not a property of a constituent, but rather a relation. It encodes the information status of a constituent relative to the rest of the utterance. If a constituent is focused, then the rest of the utterance is backgrounded (or presupposed). For this reason, focus may never be a property of a single node, let alone a lexical property of that node. So in this sense, an approach that encodes focus in the syntactic computation, such as the feature-driven approaches, will always violate Inclusiveness. (See Szendrői 2004 and Neeleman and Szendrői 2004 for further discussion on this issue.)

subsection.heading: 5 Conclusion
subsection.p: This chapter was concerned with focus movement. A language has a ‘focus construction’ if a focused constituent (at least optionally) appears in a non-canonical syntactic position. Jackendoff's (1972) invention, the [+Focus]-feature, and Chomksy's (1976) observation that focus gives rise to weak crossover effects paved the way for an analysis of focus constructions as instances of focus movement. The analyses were presented in three groups, which also by and large correspond to their order of appearance.

The first group of analyses, which includes, for instance, Horvath (1986), regards the often-attested adjacency requirement between the focus and the V (or other functional head, like I or C) as the crucial characteristic of focus constructions. Advocates of this view argue that focus is in important respects similar to case. One of the main advantages of this view is that it is able to accommodate both preverbal and postverbal focus positions.

For the second group, which includes, for instance, Rizzi (1997), the crucial factor is that in focus constructions the focal element is often clause-initial and in complementary distribution with a wh-element. Thus they establish a parallel between focus and wh in the sense that they argue that focus movement is like wh-movement. One immediate advantage of such a view is that it easily accounts for the quantificational properties of focus constructions.

A third, newly emerging set of analyses argues that the characteristic property shared between focus in languages like English and languages like Hungarian is that focus bears main accent, in irrespective of the presence or absence of syntactic focus movement. These analyses therefore emphasize the prosodic characteristics of focus constructions. The focus-to-accent view is incompatible with the standard T-model as the architecture of the grammar, while it maintains Chomsky's (1995c) Inclusiveness condition.
